sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are spring, summer, and rainy season; those deities are called autumn and late winter, which are the fathers.

sloka: yavāgūrodano dadhi samigrāmakāmānnādyakāmendriyakāmatejaskāmānāṃ
translation: Of yavagu, tears, and curd, what is the desire that fuels the longing of the senses and the mind in various objects?

sloka: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaiv~ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti ||
translation: "Just as the root of a small piece of firewood gets consumed first in the fire, so do all evil-doers get consumed here (in this very ritual). Who knows this performs the Agnihotra ritual."

sloka: yatheha kṣudhitā bālā mātaraṃ paryupāsate | ev~ sarvāṇi bhūtānyagnihotramupāsata ityagnihotramupāsata iti ||
translation: Just as a hungry child serves the mother, one should worship all beings as the agnihotra (a fire ritual).

sloka: agnayo vai trayī vidyā devayānaḥ panthā gārhapatya ṛk pṛthivī rathantaramanvāhāryapacanaḥ yajurantarikṣaṃ vāmadevyamāhavanīyaḥ sāma suvargo loko bṛhattasmādagnīn paramaṃ vadanti || ||
translation: The threefold knowledge, namely trayi vidya, is the path of the devas . Among them, gArhapatya is the ṛk associated with earth , ahireva pacana is with antarikṣa , vAmadevya is with vānī , and agni is the means to reach the heavenly world . Therefore, it is said that agni is the supreme means .

sloka: agnihotra~ sāyaṃ prātargṛhāṇāṃ niṣkṛtiḥ sviṣṭa~ suhutaṃ yajñakratūnāṃ prāyaṇa~ suvargasya lokasya jyotistasmādagnihotra~ paramaṃ vadanti ||
translation: The final ritual of agnihotra, performed during the evening and morning, is the essential rite of purification for homes. It is described as the most excellent among sacrifices, for it illuminates the path to a prosperous heaven.

sloka: vasanti prāṇino yatra |
translation: Where dwell living beings.

sloka: tataḥ tu irāvatīm nāma jajñe bhadramadā sutām | tasyāḥ tu airāvataḥ putro lokanātho mahāgajaḥ ||
translation: Then was born Iravati, the daughter of Bhadra. Her son, Airavata, became the emperor of the worlds, a great elephant-king.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam ||
translation: I myself created the four-varna system, based on qualities and actions. Know me to be its unchanging creator, as well as the one who is not an agent (akartaram) in it.

sloka: eṣāmutpattyādiryathā yadā bhagavān puruṣarūpeṇa sṛṣṭiṃ kṛtavān tadāsyaśarīrāt catvāro varṇā utpannāḥ mukhato brāhmaṇāḥ bāhutaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ūruto vaiśyāḥ pādataḥ śūdrā jātāḥ
translation: When the Lord in his cosmic form brought about creation, then four social orders emerged sequentially from his body: first the brahmins from his mouth, then kshatriyas in great numbers from his arms, vaiśyas from his thighs, and śūdras from his feet.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The brahmin was born from his mouth, the kshatriya from his arms, the vaishya from his thighs, and the shudra from his feet.

sloka: āśramaḥ śāstrokta dharmmaviśeṣaḥ| āśrāmyanti svaṃ svaṃ tapaścarantyatra | sa caturvidhaḥ | brahmacaryyaṃ gārhasthyaṃ vānaprasthyaṃ sannyāsaḥ | iti smṛtiḥ || brahmacārī | gṛhī | vānaprasthaḥ | bhikṣuḥ | ityamaraḥ ||
translation: The āśrama, as defined by scripture, is a special observance; people resort to their respective āśramas to practice austerities. It is fourfold: brahmacarya, gārhasthya, vānaprastha, and sannyāsa. So says smṛti. The practitioners are known as brahmacārī, gṛhī, vānaprastha, and bhikṣu.

sloka: trayo dharmaskandhā yajño'dhyayanaṃ dānamiti prathamastapa eva dvitīyo brahmacāryācāryakulavāsī tṛtīyo'tyantamātmānamācāryakule'vasādayansarva ete puṇyalokā bhavanti brahmasa~stho'mṛtatvameti || ||
translation: The three supports of dharma are: sacrifice, study, and charity; those who first engage in these activities, then live as a student in the guru's household, and finally practice self-restraint while living in the guru's household – all such individuals attain pious worlds and ultimately achieve Brahmanhood and immortality.

sloka: yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | | | | yasmāttrayo'pyāśramiṇo jñānenānnena cānvaham | gṛhasthenaiva dhāryante tasmājjyeṣṭhāśramo gṛhī | | | |
translation: Just as all living beings depend on the wind and function accordingly, similarly all asramas (stages of life) function relying on the householder. Indeed, the knowledge of the three asramis (those who have taken up the first three stages of life) is upheld only by the householder. Therefore, the householder's stage of life is considered the highest.

sloka: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo'dhyemi yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitrya~ rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajñavidyāmetadbhagavo'dhyemi
translation: I meditate on the Rigveda as the divinely revealed first, Yajurveda as the second, Samaveda as the third, and Atharvana as the fourth; the historical accounts and ancient legends (Itihasa-Purana) form the fifth; the sixth is the Veda of Pitrya, a storehouse of divine wealth; the seventh is the Veda of Ekayana, containing knowledge of the divine (daiva), the brahma, the created world (bhutavidya), kshatra, nakshatra and serpent-deities. This I meditate upon.

sloka: so'haṃ bhagavo mantravidevāsmi nā''tmavicchuta~hyeva me bhagavoddṛśebhyastarati śokamātmaviditi so'haṃ bhagavaḥ śocāmi taṃ mā bhagavā ñchokasya parāṃ tārayatviti ta~hovāca yadvai kiṃcaitadadhyagīṣṭhānāmaivaitat
translation: I am He, the Lord, knower of mantras. Surely, I do not waver. My devotees do not fall into grief, knowing this, they consider me as the knower of the self. Therefore, I declare, "Do not grieve, may you save him from the great fear." This is what was spoken: "It is one of the highest names."

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The name indeed is Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, Atharvana, the fourth is Itihasa-Purana, the fifth is the Veda of the ancestors and riches, of divine origin, repository; who is it that does not revere this as the single embodiment of the knowledge of gods, Brahman, beings, warriors, stars, serpent deities?

sloka: yadā vai vijānātyatha satyaṃ vadati nāvijānansatyaṃ vadati vijānanneva satyaṃ vadati vijñānaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti vijñānaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one truly knows , they speak the truth . One who does not truly know does not speak the truth. But the one who truly knows speaks the truth indeed. Knowledge must be thoroughly inquired into , as stated by the Lord .

sloka: yadā vai manute'tha vijānāti nāmatvā vijānāti matvaiva vijānāti matistveva vijijñāsitavyeti matiṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one truly understands and realizes the named (individual self) as "I," then, O Lord, one should make an effort to further inquire about that very consciousness.

sloka: yadā vai śraddadhātyatha manute nāśraddadhanmanute śraddadheva manute śraddhātveva vijijñāsitavyeti śraddhāṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one truly has faith, they should ponder: "Is faith what ought to be enquired into?" Indeed, it is faith that must be investigated, O lord.

sloka: yadā vai nistiṣṭhatyatha śraddadhāti nānistiṣṭhacchraddadhāti nistiṣṭhanneva śraddadhāti niṣṭhātveva vijijñāsitavyeti niṣṭhāṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one fully commits and has firm faith, or lacks commitment yet still has belief, or only pretends to have faith while seeking genuine commitment - all such instances call for inquiry into the nature of commitment. This is the investigation that you, O Lord, should undertake.

sloka: yadā vai karotyatha nistiṣṭhati nākṛtvā nistiṣṭhati kṛtvaiva nistiṣṭhati kṛtistveva vijijñāsitavyeti kṛtiṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one should establish something, whether by doing it first or not doing it at all , is to be ascertained ; this is the established truth that must be known , O Bhagavan.

sloka: yadā vai sukhaṃ labhate'tha karoti nāsukhaṃ labdhvā karoti sukhameva labdhvā karoti sukhaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti sukhaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one acquires happiness, they should do wholesome actions and not engage in unhappiness. Having acquired happiness, one should only act to create more happiness; this is what ought to be ascertained as happiness, declared the blessed one.

sloka: vedam evābhyasennityaṃ yathākām atandritaḥ | taṃ hyasyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo'nya ucyate
translation: One should diligently and persistently study the Vedas according to one's desire. Indeed, they call this the supreme religion; all else is called irreligious behavior.

sloka: vayasaḥ karmaṇo'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca | veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyaṃ ācaranvicarediha śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅnibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu | dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāraṃ atandritaḥ ācārāllabhate hyāyurācārādīpsitāḥ prajāḥ | ācārāddhanaṃ akṣayyaṃ ācāro hantyalakṣaṇam
translation: In this world, one should scrupulously follow the conduct that is the root of righteousness, unwaveringly. Such a conduct, resembling speech, intellect, and being appropriately restrained in one's own actions, is illuminated by both scripture and tradition. For, such conduct, endowed with good character, brings about long life, desired offspring, and inexhaustible wealth; it is said to be the marker of one's destruction when abandoned.

sloka: kaṇādena tu saṃproktaṃ śāstraṃ vaiśeṣikaṃ mahat | gautamena tathā nyāyaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ tu kapilena vai ||
translation: Informed by Kaṇāda, the extensive Vaiśeṣika Śāstra has been proclaimed; similarly, Gautama has declared Nyāya and Kapila, Sāṃkhya.

sloka: saḥ eṣaḥ saptabhiḥ puruṣairnipaṉna ekaḥ puruṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ virāṭ abhūt evaṃ liṅgaśarīrābhimānihiraṇyagarbhakartṛkā virāḍutpattiruktā tasya virājo'gnirūpatāmāha sa yaḥ puruṣaḥ iti sa prajāpatiḥ eva ayaṃ cīyamānaḥ agniḥ ityarthaḥ kāṇḍikā atha yo garbho'ntarāsīt so'gnirasṛjyata sa yadasya sarvasyāgramasṛjyata tasmādagniḥ agnirhavai tamagnirityācakṣate paro'kṣam paro'kṣakāmā hi devāḥ kāṇḍikā
translation: This one, having been united with seven purushas, became the single purusha, prajapati, and virat. Thus, the form of his linga-sharira is described as hiranyagarbha, the creator of all. The one who is called "purusha" is indeed prajapati. This fire being kindled is called agni, signifying its role in the manifestation of all that is to be created. Furthermore, the garbha that existed within was born as agni, and from him was created everything that was to be created. Therefore, he is called agni, the one who is beyond the understanding of ordinary beings, and who is desired upon by the celestial devas.

sloka: medhāyai manase'gnaye svāheti medhayā vai manasābhigacchati yajeyeti tadasyetadamubhayamātmanyeva yanmedhā ca manaśca te asminnete ubhe devate ātmanyādhīte
translation: For the sacrifice to the god of intelligence (Agni), one should approach with a concentrated mind (manas) using "svaha" as the offering mantra. This very act of offering becomes an offering to oneself, for it is through intelligence and mind that one truly offers to the divine residing within (atmanyadhite).

sloka: sa tvamagniṃ svargyamadhyeṣi mṛtyo prabrūhi tvaṃ śraddadhānāya mahyam | svargalokā amṛtatvaṃ bhajanta etad dvitīyena vṛṇe vareṇa || ||
translation: You indeed know that heavenly fire in the middle; speak to me, who is devoted. I desire immortality in heaven as my second choice; this is what I choose with a superior preference.

sloka: atha hāgnaya: samūdire tapto brahmacārī kuśalaṃ na: paryacārīddhantāsmai prabravāmeti tasmai hocu: || ||
translation: Then, O Agnaya, having undergone rigorous spiritual discipline, (you) should speak kindly to that Brahmachari. Let it be so.

sloka: atha hainaṃ gārhapatyo'nu śaśāsa pṛthivyagnirannamāditya iti ya | eṣa āditye puruṣo dṛśyate so'hamasmi sa evāhamasmīti || ||
translation: Then the earth's Fire (Agni) named Gārhapatya commanded this one: "Who is that person seen in the sun (Āditya), the one who consumes offerings?" I am he, I am indeed.

sloka: yadā lelāyate hṛārci: samiddhe havyavāhane tadājyabhāgāvantareṇāhutī: pratipādayet
translation: When the fire of sacrifice is blazing, then offerings of clarified butter should be placed in the portion of the fire belonging to the oblation by one who chants the hymns at the time when it is being kindled .

sloka: kālī karālī ca manojavā ca sulohitā yā ca sudhūmravarṇā sphuliṅginīṃ viśvarucī ca devī lelāyamānā iti sapta jihvā:
translation: The seven [sapta] tongues [jihvāḥ] of the goddess [devī], namely Kālī, Karālī, Manojavā, Sulohitā, Sudhūmravarṇā, Sphuliṅginī, and Viśvarucī, are engaging in activity [lelāyamānāḥ].

sloka: śākalyaseya śataṃ śiṣyā naiṣṭhikabrahmacāriṇaḥ pañca teṣāṃ gṛhasthāste dharmaniṣṭhāśca kuṭumbinaḥ śiśiro vāṣkalo sāṃkhyo vātsyaścaivāśvalāyanaḥ pañcaite śākalāḥ śiṣyāḥ śākhābhedapravarttakāḥ
translation: The five disciples of Śākalyaseya are a perpetual celibate student, a householder firm in his duties, a family man, an ascetic named Śiśira, and one known as Vāṣkala Sāṃkhya and Vātsya Āśvalāyana. These five disciples propagated the teachings of different branches (of this philosophical school).

sloka: ijyate'neneti yajuḥ
translation: The Yajur verse states, "This is used in the worship."

sloka: aniyatākṣarāvasāno yajuḥ ||
translation: The Yajur Veda, with unlimited/unspecified number of syllables/words.

sloka: gadyātmako yajuḥ
translation: The essence of the Yajurveda is in prose form.

sloka: ādityānīmāni śuklāni yajūṃṣi vājasaneyena yājñavalkyenākhyāyante
translation: These bright hymns, known as the Yajurveda's Vajasaneyi section, are referred to as the "Ādityas."

sloka: sā cāmaśceti tatsāmnaḥ sāmatvam |
translation: She indeed, along with āma, has achieved equality with that (sāman).

sloka: vedānāṃ sāmavedosmi |
translation: I am the Rigveda, the SamaVEDA among the Vedas.

sloka: ‘karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The rituals or duties that incite action are the Brahmanas (authoritative scriptural texts).

sloka: araṇye'dhīyūrān
translation: Those who have taken up the sacred vow in the wilderness.

sloka: vaiśvānaraḥ praviśati atithirbrāhmaṇo gṛhān | tasyaitā~ śāntiṃ kurvanti hara vaivasvatodakam || ||
translation: The all-pervading fire (Vaisvanara) enters, as a respectable guest, the Brahmin's home. They (the hosts) create peace for him by offering the water of Vasu (fire-god).

sloka: āśāpratīkṣe saṅgata~ sūnṛtāṃ ca iṣṭāpūrte putrapaśū~śca sarvān | etadvṛṅkte puruṣasyālpamedhaso yasyānaśnanvasati brāhmaṇo gṛhe || ||
translation: A small-minded householder Brahmin, who entertains guests, speaks pleasantly, and ensures the satisfaction of all, is able to fulfill this meritorious deed.

sloka: ki~svidyamasya kartavyaṃ yanmayā'dya kariṣyati || ||
translation: What is the task that must be done today, which I will accomplish?

sloka: śāntasaṅkalpaḥ sumanā yathā syādvītamanyurgautamo mābhimṛtyo | tvatprasṛṣṭaṃ mā'bhivadetpratīta etat trayāṇāṃ prathama varaṃ vṛṇe || ||
translation: With a calm mind and good intentions, just as Gautama did, I choose as my first preference the one who, free from anger, has been sent by you and is recognized by all three.

sloka: yathā purastādbhavitā pratīta auddālakirāruṇirmatprasṛṣṭaḥ | sukha~ rātrīḥ śayitā vītamanyuḥ tvāṃ dadṛśivānmṛtyumukhāt pramuktam || ||
translation: As previously seen, at dawn, untroubled and free from anger, lying on comfortable nights, Uddalaka's son Rudra, emerging in a reddish hue, had observed you freed from the jaws of death.

sloka: svarge loke na bhayaṃ kiñcanāsti na tatra tvaṃ na jarayā bibheti | ubhe tīrtvā aśanāyāpipāse śokātigo modate svargaloke || ||
translation: In the heavenly world, there is no fear whatsoever; neither should you fear aging there. Having crossed over both hunger and thirst, as well as grief, one happily delights in the heavenly world.

sloka: sa tvamagni~ svargyamadhyeṣi mṛtyo prabrūhi tva~ śraddadhānāya mahyam | svargalokā amṛtatvaṃ bhajanta etad dvitīyena vṛṇe vareṇa || ||
translation: You indeed know the path to heaven that leads to svargyam and is free from death. Obeisance to you, reveal this truth to me who has faith. I choose immortality in svargalokaa as my second choice.

sloka: prate bravīmi tadu me nibodha svargyamagniṃ naciketaḥ prajānan | anantalokāptimatho pratiṣṭhāṃ viddhi tvametaṃ nihitaṃ guhāyām || ||
translation: I declare to you, understand now this sacrifice leading to heaven, O Naciketa. Know this as my settled abode, the infinite treasure of worlds, and the foundation of all things, hidden in the cave of the heart.

sloka: lokādimagniṃ tamuvāca tasmai yā iṣṭakā yāvatīrvā yathā vā | sa cāpi tatpratyavadadyathoktaṃ athāsya mṛtyuḥ punarevāha tuṣṭaḥ || ||
translation: To the foremost in the world, who was the fire of creation, he spoke who was addressed and asked: "As many offerings as you desire and are able, speak to me what I have said." Then, satisfied, death came to him again.

sloka: tamabravītprīyamāṇo mahātmā varaṃ tavehādya dadāmi bhūyaḥ | tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa || ||
translation: The magnanimous one, pleased, said to him: "I give you a special boon today, and furthermore, this fire will be known by your name; take hold of its multiform appearance."

sloka: yeyaṃ prete vicikitsā manuṣye astītyeke nāyamastīti caike | etadvidyāmanuśiṣṭastvayā'haṃ varāṇāmeṣa varastṛtīyaḥ || ||
translation: The one who has doubts about the deceased, saying 'exists' or 'does not exist', should be taught this knowledge - of the threefold distinction among superior, middling, and inferior [types of afterlife]. I am indeed the teacher of that.

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ purā na hi suvijñeyamaṇureṣa dharmaḥ | anyaṃ varaṃ naciketo vṛṇīṣva mā moparotsīrati mā sṛjainam || ||
translation: Even the gods have pondered over this before, it is not easily understood - this dharma; Narada, choose another option, lest he sets it in motion or creates it.

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ kila tvaṃ ca mṛtyo yanna sujñeyamāttha | vaktā cāsya tvādṛganyo na labhyo nānyo varastulya etasya kaścit || ||
translation: Even by the gods has been doubted this (mystery of) death; you too have thought about it. And who else but you could explain it? Such a capable explainer is not to be found elsewhere. There is no one equal to you in possessing this (knowledge).

sloka: yasminnidaṃ vicikitsanti mṛtyo yatsāmparāye mahati brūhi nastat | yo'yaṃ varo gūḍhamanupraviṣṭo nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte || ||
translation: In which is this disputed by death at the great approaching ; tell us about it . This reward , hidden and entered , of him should not be chosen by anyone other than Nahvala .

sloka: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā | astīti bruvato'nyatra kathaṃ tadupalabhyate || ||
translation: "It cannot be obtained either through speech or mind, nor can it be seen by the eyes. But how is it attained otherwise, if one believes it to be non-existent?"

sloka: astītyevopalabdhavyastattvabhāvena cobhayoḥ | astītyevopalabdhasya tattvabhāvaḥ prasīdati || ||
translation: Upon realizing the true nature of both "asti" (existence) and "iva utpaadana" (illusion of creation), the understanding of their true essence flourishes.

sloka: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye'sya hṛdi śritāḥ | atha martyo'mṛto bhavatyatra brahma samaśnute || ||
translation: When all desires that are dwelling in his heart are abandoned, then the mortal becomes immortal; at that point, he attains union with Brahman.

sloka: etaddhyevākṣaraṃ brahma etaddhyevākṣaraṃ param | etaddhyevākṣaraṃ jñātvā yo yadicchati tasya tat || ||
translation: This single syllable "akṣara" is the ultimate Brahman; knowing this alone fulfills whatever one desires.

sloka: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ | taṃ svāccharīrātpravṛhenmuñjādiveṣīkāṃ dhairyeṇa | taṃ vidyācchukramamṛtaṃ taṃ vidyācchukramamṛtamiti || ||
translation: The self within, of the size of a thumb, always resides in the heart of all beings. One should extract, with steadfastness, from one's own body, that which is subtle, immortal, and identical to knowledge. This, truly, is the imperishable nectar.

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū | brahmajajñaṃ devamīḍyaṃ viditvā nicāyya mā~ śāntimatyantameti || ||
translation: Having mastered the threefold knowledge of the fire ritual, transcending the cycle of birth and death through identifying the divine being, called "Triṇāciketa," who is beyond the three qualities (of nature), and taking refuge in the Brahmanjajña, one attains eternal peace.

sloka: triṇāciketastrayametadviditvā ya evaṃ vidvā~ ścinute nāciketam | sa mṛtyupāśānpurataḥ praṇodya śokātigo modate svargaloke || ||
translation: Having understood the three foot-long fires and becoming wise, one who meditates on (the fire) named Naciketa in this way, will, at the threshold of death, rejoice without grief in the heavenly world.

sloka: pratigrahasamartho'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet | pratigraheṇa hyasyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati naitādṛśaḥ paro dharmo nṛṇāṃ saddharmamicchatām nyāso daṇḍasya bhūteṣu manovākkāyajasya yaḥ
translation: Even if one is capable of accepting gifts, they should avoid that situation. Accepting gifts quickly dulls the Brahmanical brilliance; such a giving up of the staff by humans seeking to follow their true dharma is not to be considered equal to other actions.

sloka: yathā candraśca rohiṇyāmurmilāyāṃ dhaneśvaraḥ|| yatra rājā vaivasvato yatrāvarodhanaṃ divaḥ yatrāmūryahvatīrāpastatra māmamṛtaṃ kṛdhīndrāyendo pari srava
translation: Just as the moon shines forth in Rohini's presence, so may Indra cause me to become immortal there where the king Vaivasvata rules , and the sun rises , and wealth is distributed .

sloka: tisro dyāvaḥ savitura dvā upasthāṃ ekā yamasya bhuvane virāṣāṭa āṇiṃ na rathyamamṛtādhi tasthuriha bravītu ya u tacciketat
translation: Three dyavas (heavens) of Savitar, two approach equally, in the realm of Yama is a single pillar that stands firm, not to be moved by even the nectar of immortality. Let one who knows this speak here.

sloka: naciketamupākhyānaṃ mṛtyuproktaṃ sanātanam
translation: The timeless tale of Naciketa's encounter with death.

sloka: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye sanniviṣṭaḥ
translation: A being, as small as a thumb, always dwells within the heart of all beings.

sloka: dharati lokān dhriyate puṇyātmabhiriti vā |
translation: The earth supports (dharati) the worlds (lokan), while being sustained (dhriyate) by the pious (puṇya) souls (ātmabhih); this is the belief (iti vā).

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: A brahmana is to be known by birth; a dvija (twice-born) by samskaras (rituals). Through learning, one becomes a vipra (priest). The three signs of a shrotriya (one who knows the Vedic teachings) are essential for determining prayashchitta (expiation).

sloka: ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī ||| ||
translation: From ether (akasha) arises air (vayu), from air arises fire (agni), from fire arises water (apah), and from water arises earth (prithivi).

sloka: dyaurme pitā janitā nābhiratra bandhurme mātā pṛthivī mahīyam |||
translation: The one who sustains above is my father, the navel here is my kin, the earth is my mother, and this expansive one is surely mine.

sloka: mātā bhūmiḥ putro'haṃ pṛthivyāḥ ||
translation: I am the son of earth's mother.

sloka: yatte bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipraṃ tadapi rohatu | mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayamarpipam ||
translation: Whatever I swiftly dig up from the earth, may that also quickly sprout. Oh soul, let your hidden depths not be pierced, nor your heart made transparent.

sloka: upasthāste anamīvā ayakṣmā asmabhyaṃ santu pṛthivi prasūtāḥ | dīrghaṃ na āyuḥ pratibudhyamānā vayaṃ tubhyaṃ balihṛtaḥ syāma ||
translation: May the earth, free from diseases and faults, always be auspiciously present for us. Emerging with long life, we will be devoted to you, having offered our strength.

sloka: indro yātūnāmabhavatparāśaro havirmathīnāmabhyā vivāsatām abhīdu śakraḥ paraśuryathā vanaṃ pātreva bhindantsata eti rakṣasaḥ
translation: Indra, like a wood-cutter with an ax, split apart the combined strength of the enemies who were offering the Soma sacrifice, just as a thunderbolt does to the forest; thus he is known as Śakra.

sloka: nahi nu yādadhīmasīndraṃ ko vīryā paraḥ tasminnṛmṇamuta kratuṃ devā ojāṃsi saṃ dadhurarcannanu svarājyam
translation: "No one, indeed, can surpass Indra in might, in that realm where the gods have bestowed their strength and performance of ritual actions, along with sacred grace and sovereignty."

sloka: indrasyāṅagirasāṃ ceṣṭau vidat saramā tanayāya dhāsim bṛhaspatirbhinadadriṃ vidad gāḥ samusriyābhirvāvaśanta naraḥ evaṃ purā svānapi sodarān sa garbhasthitānujjarituṃ bhayārtaḥ| bibheda vajreṇa tataḥ sa gotrabhit khyāto
translation: Just as in the past, Brhaspati, with his thunderbolt-like speech, shattered the mountain for the sake of Sarama's son. So did a man, filled with fear, manage to break open the womb that held his own kin. Thus was he known as one who has split his lineage.

sloka: devā ūcurindro vai devānāmojiṣṭho baliṣṭhaḥ sahiṣṭhaḥ sattamaḥ pārayiṣṇutamastaṃ
translation: The gods said, "Indra is indeed the most excellent among the gods in terms of strength, superiority, and virtuous conduct. Strive to reach him."

sloka: pūrvaṃ kṛtayuge tāta parvatāḥ pakṣiṇo'bhavan te hi jagmurdiśaḥ sarvā garuḍānilaveginaḥ
translation: In the previous age, O dear one, mountains became birds, indeed they all went in various directions, endowed with the speed of Garuda and the wind.

sloka: tatasteṣu prayāteṣu devasaṃghaḥ saharṣibhiḥ bhūtāni ca bhayaṃ jagmusteṣāṃ patanaśaṅkayā
translation: Then, as the time of departure approached, the company of gods and sages felt fear for their descent due to uncertainty.

sloka: tataḥ kruddhaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ parvatānāṃ śatakratuḥ pakṣān ciccheda vajreṇa tatra tatra sahasraśaḥ
translation: Then, angered, Indra of a thousand eyes, wielding his thunderbolt, split the wings of the mountains again and again in that place.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam |
translation: One should not be neglectful toward the duties pertaining to both the gods and one's ancestors.

sloka: nṛyajño'tithipūjanam
translation: A worship of guests is a sacrifice for men.

sloka: mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava |
translation: Become a revered mother, become a revered father, become a revered teacher, become a revered guest.

sloka: rājartviksnātakagurūnpriyaśvaśuramātulān | arhayenmadhuparkeṇa parisaṃvatsarātpunaḥ | | | | saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: The king, at the beginning of the season, should honor the respected guru, dear father-in-law, and maternal uncle with a feast. He should offer a seat, water, and food according to their due respects, as well as according to his ability, in a dignified manner.

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation: The three qualities born of nature—sattva, rajas, and tamas—restrain the imperishable self within the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: Purity prevails in happiness, passion in activity, O Bhārata; knowledge , when covered by delusion , turns into darkness .

sloka: rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṃ tamaścaiva tamaḥ sattvaṃ rajastathā ||
translation: By overcoming Rajas and Tamas, O Bharata, Sattva prevails; similarly, when Sattva and Rajas override Tamas, it also prevails.

sloka: māṃ ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇānsamatītyaitānbrahmabhūyāya kalpate || brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāhamamṛtasyāvyayasya ca | śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca ||
translation: One who devoutly serves Me without deviation from bhakti-yoga can surpass these material qualities and become eligible for becoming one with Brahman. Indeed, I am the foundation of Brahman, immortality, imperishable nature, eternal religion, and ultimate happiness.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣeyaḥ yonāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñāātaṃ vijñātamiti kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti
translation: How can that which is unseen and unknown, yet heard and inferred, be called a command by you, Lord?

sloka: hovācānanuśiṣya vāva kila mā bhagavānabravīdanutvā'śiṣamiti
translation: The teacher, indeed, said to him: "Do not neglect the instruction, O lord."

sloka: pañca mā rājanyabandhuḥ praśrnāprākṣītteṣāṃ naikaṃ ca nāśakaṃ vivaktumiti
translation: Five words, O royal relative, should not be spoken separately in their entirety: not one, and also not the destructive one.

sloka: sa hovāca yathā mā tvaṃ tadaitānavado yathā'hameṣāṃ naikaṃ ca na veda yadyahamimānavediṣyaṃ kathaṃ te nāvakṣyāmiti
translation: He (the teacher) said: "How can I not inform you (the student) about this matter, when I myself do not fully know even one of them? If I am to teach these (topics), then how wouldn't I be able to speak?"

sloka: mānuṣasya bhagavangautama vittasya varaṃ vṛṇīthā iti
translation: Bhagavan Gautama, choose the best among human wealth.

sloka: sa hovāca tavaiva rājanmānuṣaṃ vittaṃ yāmeva kumārasyānte vācamabhāṣathāstāmeva me brūhiti sa ha kṛcchrī babhūva
translation: The king asked, "It was you who spoke to the boy at his death. Tell me, what did you say that made him so distressed?"

sloka: sūryaḥ dyusthānaḥ | vāyuḥ vā indraḥ vā antarikṣasthānaḥ | agniḥ pṛthivīsthānaḥ |
translation: The sun is in its position in the sky, or perhaps it is the wind, or maybe Indra that is in the mid-region; alternatively, it could be fire in its position on earth.

sloka: aṅgayanti agyraṃ janma prāpayanti itivyutpattyā aṅgati ūrddhvaṃ gacchati iti agi gatau ||
translation: Generating life in the womb, bringing forth the formless into form, as it rises upwards, having reached completion - such is the course of nature.

sloka: sa vā eṣo'gre devatānāmajāyatā tasmādagrirnāmāgrirha vai nāmaitadyadagnirityāhuḥ sa u jātaḥ pūrvaḥ prayāya tadvaivāsya dvitīyamagritvaṃ pūrvaṃhi yantamāhuragra etīti ||
translation: This very first-born deity of the name Agni was generated at the beginning. Therefore, "agri" is the name given to the beginning and "agra" to the dwelling that is there. That which is called "Agni" in this way has already manifested before and will continue to do so. Its second appearance is referred to as "dvitīyam agritvam," with its initial form being "pūrvam." Indeed, it moves toward what is ahead, as is commonly understood.

sloka: prajāpatirha vā idamagra eka evāsa | sa aikṣata kathaṃ nu prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata so'gnimeva mukhājjanayāṃcakre tadyadenaṃ mukhādajanayata tasmādannādo'gniḥ
translation: The creator thought, "How will this unique being produce offspring?" After reflection, he performed severe austerities . From his mouth , he created fire , for it is from here that fire originated. Therefore , fire is called the eater of the initial offering .

sloka: agnimūrdhā cakṣuṣī candrasūryau diśa: śrotre vāgvivṛtāśca vedā: vāyu: prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhayāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā sthālīsthānaṃ gato'śvatthaṃ śamīgarbhaṃ vilakṣya saḥ | tena dve araṇī kṛtvā urvaśīlokakāmyayā || ||
translation: With agni (fire) residing at the crown, the sun and moon as eyes, the directions as ears, speech as the surrounding (vṛtāḥ) enclosure, the air as life force (prāṇaḥ), the universe's heart in the form of space between the two feet, and this entire world inside as the inner self – having recognized the banyan tree (aśvatthaṃ) within the seed of a shrub (śamī garbham) – using two pieces of wood (dve araṇī), perform the act with desire for Urvaśī's love.

sloka: urvaśīṃ mantrato dhyāyan adharāraṇimuttarām | ātmānaṃ ubhayormadhye yattat prajananaṃ prabhuḥ || ||
translation: Meditating on Urvasi, contemplating the higher and lower regions, the Lord located in both places recognizes himself.

sloka: tasya nirmanthanāt jāto jātavedā vibhāvasuḥ | trayyā sa vidyayā rājñā putratve kalpitastrivṛt || ||
translation: Born from his churning, Jātavedas, the expansive one, was brought into existence by him with the three-fold knowledge, specifically for the purpose of offspring.

sloka: jātavedāḥ kasmāt | jātavit yaḥ vā jātaprajñānaḥ | jātāni veda | tasya eṣā bhavati | jāte jāte vidyate iti vā | jātadhanaḥ |
translation: Born-of-fire (Agni), why is he called so? The one who has fully developed consciousness and knows all that is born. His (Agni's) wealth consists of this knowledge of the birth of everything. This is indeed his inherent nature; it exists at his very birth, and there is nothing other than this knowledge that can be attributed to him at any time.

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {siddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established conclusion regarding the acceptance of the authority in a tantra system

sloka: dvividho hi vedokto dharmaḥ pravṛttilakṣaṇo nivṛttilakṣaṇaśca jagataḥ stithikāraṇam prāṇināṃ sākṣādabhyudayaniḥśreyasaheturya
translation: The two types of dharma, as described in the Vedas, are characterized by their association with pravrtti (worldly engagement) and nivrtti (renunciation). They serve to establish equilibrium for living beings and directly contribute to their upliftment and ultimate well-being.

sloka: hiṃsraṃ dravyamayaṃ kāmyamagnihotrādyaśāntidam darśaśca pūrṇamāsaśca cāturmāsyaṃ paśuḥ sutaḥ etadiṣṭaṃ pravṛttākhyaṃ hutaṃ prahutameva ca pūrtaṃ surālayārāma kūpā jīvyādilakṣaṇam
translation: The offering in the new moon and full moon sacrifices, including the first offering in the fire rituals, is consumable wealth used for indulgence; this includes the animal sacrifice of the (four-month) celebration, offspring, what is designated as "this is offered," "it is being performed," "it is completely given," the gods' abode, recreational spaces, wells - all are indicative of life's sustenance.

sloka: naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṃ tava || ||
translation: My illusion has been destroyed, and through your grace, I have gained remembrance. Firmly established am I now, without doubt, ready to carry out your command.

sloka: saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau | tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate || ||
translation: Renunciation of actions and action through yoga both lead to liberation. However, the latter is superior due to the renunciation of actions .

sloka: tapasvibhyo'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo'pi mato'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna || ||
translation: A yogi is superior to ascetics and even more so than one who is wise; a yogi is also superior to those who are active in their duties. Therefore, become a yogi, Arjuna.

sloka: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṃ tatam || ||
translation: The supreme being, O Partha, is attainable only through devotion and not in any other way. All beings and elements within them are established in him, and it is he who pervades all this.

sloka: udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me matam | āsthitaḥ sa hi yuktātmā māmevānuttamāṃ gatim || ||
translation: All of them are generous (udarah) and, in my opinion (matam), the knower of the self (jnani) is superior. For, one who is established (asthtih) in the self (atma) is truly situated (yukta) and attains (gatim) the supreme (anuttamam) path to me (mam).

sloka: tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara | asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, always act dedicated to your duty, for a person unattached to the result attains the supreme.

sloka: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā || ||
translation: One who performs actions, having placed them in Brahman, abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just like a lotus leaf in water.

sloka: sarvopaniṣado gāvo dogdhā gopālanandanaḥ | pārtho vatsaḥ sudhīrbhoktā dugdhaṃ gītāmṛtaṃ mahat ||
translation: All the Upanishads are like cows, yielding the milk of knowledge; Gopala's (Krishna's) devotee Partha (Arjuna) is the calf who drinks this milk, the nectar of the Gita's teachings.

sloka: kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīti || ||
translation: By understanding whom, O blessed one, everything in this context becomes known.

sloka: mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ| manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati||||
translation: I, the eternal soul, am a fraction of him in this world, abiding in living beings; the five organs of perception and the mind constantly engage with the objects of their function, according to their inherent nature.

sloka: virāṭsutāḥ somasadaḥ sādhyānāṃ pitaraḥ smṛtāḥ | agniṣvāttāśca devānāṃ mārīcā lokaviśrutāḥ daityadānavayakṣāṇāṃ gandharvoragarakṣasām | suparṇakinnarāṇāṃ ca smṛtā barhiṣado'trijāḥ
translation: Sons of Virat are remembered as the fathers of the Sadhyas, Agni-like to the gods, famous in the world to the daityas, danavas, and yakshas, gandharvas, serpents, and rakshasas. To the suparnas and kinnaras, they are known as the sons of Atri.

sloka: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ somapāstu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ | pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ
translation: The one who partakes in the Soma sacrifice is known as "Soma" among the brahmins, and as "Havirbhuja" among the kshatriyas. Among the vaishyas, he is called "Ajya" and among the shudras, "Sukalina". The sons of the sage Kave, who are experts in sacrifices, are named "Somapas", while Pulastya's and Vasistha's sons are known as "Ajyapas".

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are spring, summer, and the rainy season; these are the divine ritus (natural cycles or time periods). Autumn, late autumn, and cool weather – these are the seasons called the fathers.

sloka: kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajoguṇasamudbhavaḥ | mahāśano mahāpāpmā viddhyenamiha vairiṇam ||
translation: This desire and anger, born of the mode of passion, are indeed great enemies; know them to be insatiable and sinful.

sloka: kāmamāśritya duṣpūraṃ dambhamānamadānvitāḥ | mohādgṛhītvāsadgrāhānpravartante'śucivratāḥ ||
translation: Relying on desire, accompanied by arrogance and pride, and through delusion taking hold of unholy practices, they begin to act.

sloka: ahan vṛtraṃ vṛtrataraṃ vyaṃsamindro vajreṇa mahatā vadhena | skandhāṃsīva kuliśenā vivṛkṇā'hi: śayata upapṛk pṛthivyāḥ ||
translation: I, Indra, have struck down Vrtra, the greatest of asuras, with a powerful thunderbolt. Like a tree, have I split open the ridges of the earth.

sloka: tava cyautnāni vajrahasta tāni nava yatpuro navatiṃ ca sadyaḥ niveśane śatatamāviveṣīrahañca vartraṃ namucimutāhan
translation: Your thunderbolt-like efforts, those nine, newly in this very moment have you thoroughly examined and annihilated the enemy named Namuchi in the battle.

sloka: śateṣu jāyate śūraḥ sahasreṣu ca paṇḍitaḥ | vaktā śatasahasreṣu dātā bhavati vā na vā ||
translation: In a hundred (situations), a warrior is born, and among thousands, a scholar. Occasionally, one becomes a speaker in a hundred, or maybe not even a giver.

sloka: kuṭumbabharaṇāddravyaṃ yatkiṃcidatiricyate | taddeyaṃ upahṛtyānyaddadaddoṣaṃ avāpnuyāt | | | |
translation: Whatever wealth exceeding household needs is acquired, by giving away a portion of that and the rest without fault, one does not incur blame.

sloka: indriyaprītyarthasya tu bhikṣaṇamanimittam | na tadādriyeta ::: yoktā ca dharmayukteṣu dravyaparigraheṣu ca ::: pratipādayitā ca tīrthe :::
translation: The alms seeking for the purpose of sensory pleasure is the proximate cause (of renunciation). One should not become attached to it. Also, one who engages in religious duties while also acquiring material possessions and one who establishes (others) in sacred places (should follow this principle).

sloka: yantā cātīrthe yato na bhayaṃ syāt ::: saṃgrahītā ca manuṣyān :::
translation: Where rulers lead such that there is no fear at the holy sites, and they are able to gather people.

sloka: deśataḥ kālataḥ śaucataḥ samyak pratigrahītṛta iti dānāni pratipādayati :::
translation: He lays down gifts that are appropriate according to place, time, and purity, as well as being given with complete sincerity.

sloka: mekhalādhāraṇabhaikṣacaryadaṇḍasamidādhānopasparśanaprātarabhivādā nityam
translation: Daily in the early morning, one should always touch (on being offered) the girdle, staff, and fire of a religious mendicant.

sloka: brahma jñānaṃ tapo vā ācarati arjayatyavaśyam| upanayanānantaraṃ niyamaṃ kṛtvā guroḥ sannidhausthitvā sāṅgavedādhyayanaṃ karoti yaḥ | sa dbividhaḥ upakurvvāṇaḥ naiṣṭhikaśca | prathamāśramī |
translation: The one who, having undergone the upanayana ceremony, strictly follows the rules in the presence of the guru, first undertakes the study of the Angas (limbs) of Veda, is a twice-born who is engaged in both prescribed and unprescribed activities, and is firmly established in asceticism; indeed, such an individual has acquired spiritual knowledge and austerity.

sloka: codito guruṇā nityaṃ apracodita eva vā | kuryādadhyayane yatnaṃ ācāryasya hiteṣu ca | | | |
translation: One should always make an effort to study (adhyayane) and serve the guru, whether instructed (coditaḥ) by them or not (apracoditaḥ), as well as (ca) in other duties beneficial (hiteṣu) to the guru.

sloka: uṣitvaivaṃ gurukule dvijo'dhītyāvabudhya ca | trayīṃ sāṅgopaniṣadaṃ yāvadarthaṃ yathābalam || ||
translation: Having resided in the teacher's home, the twice-born person should make an effort to understand the integrated triple science and its meaning to the best of their ability.

sloka: vedayajñairahīnānāṃ praśastānāṃ svakarmasu | brahmacāryāharedbhaikṣaṃ gṛhebhyaḥ prayato'nvaham | | | | guroḥ kule na bhikṣeta na jñātikulabandhuṣu | alābhe tvanyagehānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ vivarjayet | | | | sarvaṃ vāpi caredgrāmaṃ pūrvoktānāṃ asaṃbhave | niyamya prayato vācaṃ abhiśastāṃstu varjayet | | | |
translation: For those in this world who are virtuous and have praised their own duties, they should eat only bare necessities and practice celibacy while leaving home daily; they should not beg for alms in the guru's family or among relatives, but instead avoid other houses in the initial stages. If there is a scarcity of food in all other places, then they may take up living in a village, following the previously mentioned rules. They should control their speech and avoid harsh words.

sloka: brahmacārī vratī nityaṃ nityaṃ dīkṣāparo vaśī | gurucchāyānugo nityamadhīyānaḥ suyantritaḥ | avicālyavratopetaṃ kṛtyaṃ kurvanvasetsadā ||
translation: Constantly observing the brahmacharya vow and self-control, always engaged in the practice of diksha, constantly under the guidance of the guru, always engaged in learning – such is the unwavering duty of a disciplined person.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca || ||
translation: A virtuous, self-restrained, and disciplined person with controlled senses, who has faith and is skilled in their endeavor, performs their duties as long as necessary among women who have conquered their passions and among men who have done the same.

sloka: vasanneko japannekaḥ sarvānvedānyudhiṣṭhira | ekasminneva cācārye śuśrūṣurmalapaṅkavān ||
translation: Devoting oneself to a single guru, Yudhishthira, should diligently study all the Vedas, unsoiled by impurities such as deceit and ego.

sloka: śayyāsane'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet | śayyāsanasthaścaivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet | | | | ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hyutkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati | pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punastānpratipadyate | | | |
translation: Upon performing the duties of lying down and sitting, one does not become firmly established in the highest good. But, upon getting up and greeting him, the life-force of both young and old is raised up. After rising and greeting, one should cause them to be seated again.

sloka: śreyaḥsu guruvadvṛttiṃ nityaṃ eva samācaret | guruputreṣu cāryeṣu guroścaiva svabandhuṣu | | | | bālaḥ samānajanmā vā śiṣyo vā yajñakarmaṇi | adhyāpayangurusuto guruvanmānaṃ arhati | | | | yathā khanankhanitreṇa naro vāryadhigacchati | tathā gurugatāṃ vidyāṃ śuśrūṣuradhigacchati | | | |
translation: One should always follow the conduct of a guru, which is superior. Towards the children and disciples of the guru, as well as towards one's own relatives, such conduct is befitting. Whether it is a peer born in the same family or a student, they too should act in this way during a ritualistic sacrifice. The son of the guru deserves respect. In the same way that a person becomes respected through their actions, one attains knowledge and respect through serving the guru.

sloka: varjayenmadhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasānstriyaḥ | śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam | | | | abhyaṅgaṃ añjanaṃ cākṣṇorupānacchatradhāraṇam | kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca lobhaṃ ca nartanaṃ gītavādanam | | | | dyūtaṃ ca janavādaṃ ca parivādaṃ tathānṛtam | strīṇāṃ ca prekṣaṇālambhaṃ upaghātaṃ parasya ca | | | |
translation: Avoid at this time in the world: madhu, mamsam, gandha, mala, rasa striyaah; all harm to living beings, sharp weapons, and abuse. Also, abhyanga, anjana for the eyes, chatra dharam, kama, krodha, lobha, dance, song, gambling, janavada, parivada, falsehood, and the ogling of women.

sloka: prativedaṃ brahmacaryaṃ dvādaśābdāni pañca vā | grahaṇāntikaṃ ityeke keśāntaścaiva ṣoḍaśe | | | |
translation: "One should undertake brahmacharya (celibate student life) for a period of twelve years or five years, as some propose. Some say this should end when the hair is shaved off (during the initiation ceremony in the final year)."

sloka: vedasvīkaraṇaṃ kṛtvā srāyādvai dattadakṣiṇaḥ | naiṣṭhiko brahmacārī vā dehāntaṃ nivasedgurau ||
translation: Having accomplished the initiation rite of Vedas, and having made a gift of fee to the teacher, a perpetual student of brahminic life, either at the time of death, may take up residence with his teacher.

sloka: yadi tvātyantikaṃ vāsaṃ rocayeta guroḥ kule | yuktaḥ paricaredenaṃ ā śarīravimokṣaṇāt | | | | ācārye tu khalu prete guruputre guṇānvite | gurudāre sapiṇḍe vā guruvadvṛttiṃ ācaret | | | | eteṣvavidyamāneṣu sthānāsanavihāravān | prayuñjāno'gniśuśrūṣāṃ sādhayeddehaṃ ātmanaḥ | | | |
translation: If one desires to permanently reside in the teacher's household, they should follow the prescribed duties for bodily liberation. But if the teacher is deceased, and his son or wife, who possesses good qualities, is still alive, then one should serve them and abide by their conduct. In their absence, one should engage in performing religious activities such as fire rituals, while residing in appropriate places, for the purification of the self.

sloka: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryaṃ aviplutaḥ | sa gacchatyuttamasthānaṃ na ceha jāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: One who acts thus, the virtuous brahmin, constantly practicing celibacy, attains the highest place and never returns.

sloka: anena vidhinā dehaṃ sādayanvijitendriyaḥ | brahmalokaṃ avāpnoti na cehājāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: By following this rule, a self-controlled person with mastery over the senses attains the abode of Brahma after abandoning the body and does not return.

sloka: āvasathyādhānaṃ dārakāle dāyādyakāla ekeṣām ||
translation: At the time of a child's birth, for some, the determination of the inheritance is done.

sloka: kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijno matimān ṛjuḥ hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā samidhaḥpāvanāḥ pūjyāḥ carmayuktāḥ parātparāḥ yuṣmān harāmi homārthaṃ asmān rakṣata sarvadā ||
translation: Is there, in your duties towards the sacred fires, any who is properly qualified, possessing wisdom and performing prescribed duties, with oblations always offered on time; are the firewood purifying and worthy of worship ever ready, protecting you and others at all times?

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The name indeed is Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvanah, the fourth; Itihasa and Purana are the fifth Vedas. Pitrya, Rashi, Daiva, Nidhi, Vaakyam, Ekaayanam, Deva, Brahma, Bhoota, Kshatra, Nakshatra, Sarpa, and knowledge of their deities – all these names should be carefully studied and contemplated upon.

sloka: mano vāva vāco bhūyo yathā vai dve vā''malake mano hyātmā mano loko mano hi brahma mana upāssveti
translation: Should one meditate on the mind, or the speech, or rather on both? Indeed, the mind is the self, the world, and Brahman; it is through the mind that one should meditate.

sloka: dhyānaṃ vāva cittādbhūyo dhyāyatīva pṛthavī dhyāyatīvāntarikṣaṃ dhyāyatīva dyaurdhyāyatīva''po dhyāyantīva parvatā dhyāyantīva devamanuṣyāstasmādya iha manuṣyāṇāṃ mahattāṃ prapnuvanti dhyānāpādā~ śā ivaiva te dhyānamupāssveti
translation:
"Meditating, indeed, on the self, one should meditate as if on something separate, like the earth, the intermediate space, the sky, mountains, and deities. Therefore, it is through this process of meditation that humans attain greatness. Thus, they ought to practice this meditation."

The verse emphasizes the importance of meditating on the self as if it were something separate from oneself, like various external objects or entities, in order to achieve greatness.

sloka: balaṃ vāva vijñānādbhūyo'pi ha śataṃ vijñānavatāseko balavānākampayate sa yadā balī bhavatyathotthātā bhavatyuttiṣṭhan paricaritā bhavati paricarannupasatta bhavatyupasīdandraṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati bodhdā bhavati balamupāssveti
translation: Power, or so it is said, becomes true power when combined with knowledge. Even if one has a hundredfold more knowledge, it is the one who applies that knowledge in practice who becomes powerful. When one becomes strong and gets up to act, engages in service, is steadfast in attentiveness, observant, a listener, contemplative, and illuminated, then they are said to be focused on power.

sloka: annaṃ vāva balādbhūyastasmādyadyapi daśarātrārnāśrnīyādyadyu ha jīvedathavā'draṣṭā'śrotā'mantā'bodhdā'kartā'vijñātā bhavatyathānnasyā''yai draṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati bodhdā bhavati kartā bhavati vijñātā bhavatyannamupāssveti
translation: Food, indeed, is considered the foremost (source of) strength. Therefore, even if one lives for only ten days, if they are a seer, hearer, ponderer, aware, doer, and knower in relation to it, then they become a seer, hearer, ponderer, aware, doer, and knower in relation to it. One should attend to food in this way.

sloka: āpo vāvānnādbhūyasyastasmādyadā suvṛṣṭirna bhavati vyādhīyante prāṇā annaṃ kanīyo bhaviṣyatītyatha yadā suvṛṣṭirbhavatyānandinaḥ prāṇā bhavantyannaṃ bahu bhaviṣyatītyāpa evemā mūrtā yeyaṃ pṛthavī yadantarikṣaṃ mūrtā apa upāssveti
translation: When there is no rain , life-breaths languish , and a scarcity of food arises. And when there is abundant rain , the earth becomes fertile and the bodies of water become full . Indeed , the waters , which are a part of the natural world , were born before the creation of this world . Just as these waters give form to the physical world , so do they also sustain all living beings .

sloka: tejo vāvādbhyo bhūyastadvā etadvāyumāgṛhnā''kāśamabhitapati tadā''hurniśocati nitapati varṣiṣyati vā iti teja eva tatpūrvaṃ darśayitvā'thāpaḥ sṛjate tadetadūrdhvābhiśca tiraścībhiśca vidyudbhirāhrādāścaranti teja upāssveti
translation: The radiant one, increasing from the waters, having enveloped the earth with its brilliance, at that moment, either burns or rains, thus revealing its true nature first, then creates clouds and thunderbolts. One should meditate upon such a radiant entity.

sloka: ākāśo vāva tejaso bhūyānākāśe vai sūryā candramasāvubhau vidyunnakṣatrāṇyagnirākāśenā''hvayatyākāśena pratiśrṛṇotyākāśe ramata ākāśe na ramata ākāśe jāyata ākāśamabhijāyata ākāśamupāssveti
translation: Is it the ether that is born from light and heat, that envelops both the sun and the moon, that the stars and fire are woven into, that resonates within the ether, that listens within the ether, that revels within the ether, that does not spring from elsewhere but from itself, that is born of itself, that should be meditated upon?

sloka: smaro vāvā''kāśādbhūyastasmādyadyapi bahava āsīranna smaranto naiva te kaṃcana śṛṇuyurnamanvīranna vijānīranyadā vāva te smareyuratha śṛṇuyuratha manvīrannatha vijānīransmareṇa vai putrānvijānāti smareṇa paśūnsmaramupāssveti
translation: Even those who were not previously mindful can now become so in various ways. But only if they learn and understand through remembering, then they will truly hear, comprehend, and know both their own children and livestock.

sloka: āśā vāva smarādbhūyasyāśeddho vai smaro mantrānadhīte karmaṇi kurute putrā~śca paśū~ścecchata imaṃ ca lokamamuṃ cecchata āśāmupāssveti
translation: The desire indeed is what the remembrance of the worthy is focused on, and the one who remembers is surely virtuous in reciting the mantras . Such a person performs actions and looks after both this world and the other world with desire .

sloka: prāṇo vā āśāyā bhūyānyathā vā arā nābhau samarpitā evamasminprāṇe sarva~samarpitaṃ prāṇaḥ prāṇena yāti prāṇaḥ prāṇaṃ dadāti prāṇāya dadāti prāṇo ha pitā prāṇo mātā prāṇo bhrātā prāṇaḥ svasā prāṇa ācāryaḥ prāṇo brahmaṇaḥ
translation: The life force (prāṇa) is called the share of hope. Alternatively, if not in the navel, it is offered here. In this very life force, everything is offered. Through the life force, the life force goes to the life force; the life force gives to the life force; the life force is the father, the mother, the brother, the sister, the teacher, and the share of Brahman.

sloka: yo vai bhūmā tatsukhaṃ nālpe sukhamasti bhūmaiva sukhaṃ bhūmā tveva vijijñāsitavya iti bhūmānaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: For surely, the true bliss is that which comes from the infinite self; there is no smaller happiness than this. The infinite self alone is to be truly known, as declared by the revered one.

sloka: yatra nānyatpaśyati nānyacchṛṇoti nānyadvijānāti sa bhūmā'tha yatrānyatpaśyatyanyacchṛṇotyanyadvijānāti tadalpaṃ yo vai bhūmā tadamṛtamatha yadalpaṃ tanmartya~sa bhagavaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti sve mahimni yadi vā na mahimnīti
translation: Where one sees nothing else, hears nothing else, and knows nothing else, that is the great; but where one sees something else, hears something else, and knows something else, that is small. Indeed, what is limited is mortal, while what is unlimited is divine. Depending on whether it is or is not established in its own greatness.

sloka: aparābādhamakleśaṃ prayatnenārjītaṃ dhanam | svalpaṃ vā vipulaṃ vāpi deyamityabhidīyate ||
translation: Wealth acquired through dedicated effort, free from causing harm and distress, is declared to be either scant or plentiful and worthy of being given away.

sloka: vyākhyā api tantrasya guṇaḥ| tābhirapi tantramalaṅikrayate | tāśca pañcadaśa prakārā |
translation: The quality of this Tantra is also its explanation; it is adorned with those fifteen aspects.

sloka: indro dadhīco asthabhirvṛtrāṇyapratiṣkutaḥ jaghāna navatīrnava
translation: Indra, with unshakeable resolve, single-handedly slew ninety sets of foes.

sloka: ichannaśvasya yacchiraḥ parvateṣvapaśritam tada vidaccharyaṇāvati
translation: Of Ich Annaśva's head that has rested on the mountains, reveal (tam) what (yat) distinguishes it from ordinary ones.

sloka: maghavān yāta bhadraṃ vo dadhyāñcamṛṣisattamam vidyāvratatapaḥsāraṃ gātraṃ yācata mā ciram
translation: Approach, Maghavan, now and quickly seek the best oblations of Dadhi, offered by the foremost sage who is steadfast in his vow of learning. Do not delay.

sloka: sa vā adhigato dadhyaṅṅaśvibhyāṃ brahma niṣkalam yad vā aśvaśiro nāma yatoramaratāṃ vyadhāt
translation: He indeed has attained the supreme knowledge, which is unchanging and beyond both the physical and subtle realms, named "Ashwashira," from where immortality is bestowed.

sloka: dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇastvaṣṭre varmābhedyaṃ madātmakam viśvarūpāya yat prādāt tvaṣṭā yat tvamadhāstataḥ
translation: "O Ātharvan Tvaṣṭre, you have granted me a weapon that cannot be defeated and is identical to your own divine nature. This universal form of yours, which you have bestowed upon me, where exactly does it reside - above or below?"

sloka: yuṣmabhyaṃ yācato'śvibhyāṃ dharmajño'ṅgāni dāsyati tatastairāyudhaśreṣṭho viśvakarmavinirmitaḥ yena vṛtraśiro hartā mattejaupabṛṃhitaḥ
translation: The one who knows dharma, when asked by you two, will gladly give his limbs. Then, the most excellent among weapons, created by all-doer, will destroy Vritra's head, embellished with Matteja.

sloka: tasmin vinihate yūyaṃ tejo'strāyudhasampadaḥ bhūyaḥ prapsyatha bhadraṃ vo na hiṃsanti ca matpurān
translation: Upon its destruction, you will regain your radiative power and weaponry. May you prosper; for they do not harm me, your ally and protector.

sloka: etaddhyevākṣaraṃ brahma etaddhyevākṣaraṃ param | etaddhyevākṣaraṃ jñātvā yo yadicchati tasya tat || ||
translation: This syllable alone is the absolute Brahman; by knowing this syllable, one gets that which they desire.

sloka: etadvai satyakāma paraṃ cāparaṃ ca brahma yadoṅkāraḥ |
translation: This indeed is the ultimate Brahman, both the manifest and unmanifest, referred to as "Om."

sloka: dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca sthitaṃ ca yacca sacca tyacca || ||
translation: The two forms of Brahman are indeed distinct: the tangible and the intangible, mortal and immortal, stationary and moving, existing and non-existing.

sloka: anyacchreyo'nyadutaiva preyaste ubhe nānārthe puruṣa~ sinītaḥ | tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya sādhu bhavati hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte || ||
translation: Choosing one over the other, depending on the situation, is beneficial for a person. By making such a choice, they act properly and avoid losing the opportunity to gain the most preferred outcome.

sloka: śreyaśca preyaśca manuṣyametaḥ tau samparītya vivinakti dhīraḥ | śreyo hi dhīro'bhi preyaso vṛṇīte preyo mando yogakṣemādvṛṇīte || ||
translation: A wise person distinguishes between what is truly beneficial and what seems pleasant to a human being when they are considered together; for a disciplined person chooses what is truly beneficial over what seems pleasant, while an ignorant person chooses what seems pleasant, neglecting their well-being and spiritual growth.

sloka: sa tvaṃ priyānpriyarūpāṃśca kāmān abhidhyāyannaciketo'tyasrākṣīḥ | naitā~ sṛṅkāṃ vittamayīmavāpto yasyāṃ majjanti bahavo manuṣyāḥ || ||
translation: You, who are not attached, contemplate on dear and lovely desires. Yet, those desires, like a vessel made of gold, have not been attained by many people and they drown in it.

sloka: dūramete viparīte viṣūcī avidyā yā ca vidyeti jñātā | vidyābhīpsinaṃ naciketasaṃ manye na tvā kāmā bahavo'lolupanta || ||
translation: To Naciketas, who is seeking knowledge, I think there is no room for many worldly desires when it comes to the one who truly knows versus the one who is ignorant of this distant, contradictory illusion called avidyā.

sloka: avidyāyāmantare vartamānāḥ svayaṃ dhīrāḥ paṇḍitaṃmanyamānāḥ | dandramyamāṇāḥ pariyanti mūḍhā andhenaiva nīyamānā yathāndhāḥ || ||
translation: Engrossed in ignorance, yet considering themselves wise, the self-deluded behave foolishly, led astray by darkness, just like the blind by a blind.

sloka: na sāmparāyaḥ pratibhāti bālaṃ pramādyantaṃ vittamohena mūḍham | ayaṃ loko nāsti para iti mānī punaḥ punarvaśamāpadyate me || ||
translation: The true nature of the world does not reveal itself to a deluded fool, infatuated by wealth and lost in the pursuit of momentary pleasure. Again and again, such a person falls into the trap of mistakenly thinking that this is the only world that exists.

sloka: ya ete pitṛdevānāmayane vedanirmite śāstreṇa cakṣuṣā veda janastho'pi na muhyati ādāvante janānāṃ sadbahirantaḥ parāvaram jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ vaco vācyaṃ tamo jyotistvayaṃ svayam
translation: The one who, with the scripture- prescribed vision, doesn't get confused by these divine ancestors' path; even while being in the midst of people's initial and final actions; for them, self-evident is the external and internal knowledge, the object of knowing, and the means of expressing it; this very one is the light dispelling darkness.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: The designators 'Agni' (fire) and 'Surya' (sun), daytime's resplendent and pure 'Rakottara' (foremost shining one in the sky beyond), self-reliant 'Svah' (brilliance), all-pervading 'Visva' (universe), introspective 'Taijasa' (inner fire), and highest 'Turya' (transcendental consciousness) are intertwined with the living being. Having become this, they proclaim that it is the divinely installed 'Devayanam' (path to the divine). This self-offered 'Atmayaji' (self as oblation), pacified by inner peace, remains steadfast in its own essence and does not retreat from itself.

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: The subtle manifestation of elements, smoke is; night and waning moon are the decay; the southern path is the Soma; Darsha is the herbal plant medicine; food is the solid form; the semen is referred to as retas; this is the cycle of birth and death for pitrs on earth; each individual, in their respective order, having experienced becomes reborn.

sloka: tadya iha ramaṇīyacaraṇā abhyāśo ha yatte ramaṇīyāṃ yonimāpadyeranbrāhmaṇayoniṃ vā kṣatriyayoniṃ vā vaiśyayoniṃ vātha ya iha kapūyacaraṇā abhyāśo ha yatte kapūyāṃ yonimāpadyeran śvayoniṃ vā sūkarayoniṃ vā caṇḍālayoniṃ vā ||
translation: Those who pursue pleasant conduct here, should they adopt a refined womb, whether of a Brahmana, Kshatriya, or Vaishya; or those who follow foul conduct, should they adopt a foul womb, whether of a dog, pig, or Chandala?

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: At the onset of its realization, one who is well-prepared becomes engaged with inquiry and examination.

sloka: samānā cāsṛtyupakramādamṛtatvaṃ cānupoṣya
translation: Constantly nurturing equality and immortality as the preliminary pursuit.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation: In the eternal cycle of this world, these two paths, the white and the black, lead to a one-way departure and a definite return.

sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: "O Agni, bring here the gods and favor the three birthplaces. Be ornamented and drink the ritual offering."

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: Indeed, the foremost to be known is the one to the south, [who is] the father; for this very son of the sacrifices, the Southern Fire, is the Gārhapatya and the Ahavaniya. Therefore, one should properly tend to him.

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: These very three are the worlds and these very three are the ashramas. These are indeed the three vedas and the three fires that are mentioned.

sloka: pitā vai gārhapatyo'gnirmātāgnirdakṣiṇāḥ smṛtāḥ | gururāhavanīyastu sāgnitretā garīyasī ||
translation: The father is remembered as the creator of the gārhapatya fire, while the mother is associated with the dakṣiṇā fire; the āhavanīya fire is considered superior and is the teacher during the tretā age.

sloka: triṣvapramādyanneteṣu trīllolokān vijayedgṛhī | dīpyamānaḥ svavapuṣāḥ devavadyivi modate ||
translation: Emerging first in the three realms by never being negligent, one who is self-illuminating rejoices like a god, holding (them) with their own form and causing them to shine.

sloka: nṛyajño'tithipūjanam
translation: A ceremony honoring the revered guest (atithi-pujanam) is a religious duty performed for a deity in human form (nryajnah).

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: Having accomplished this Kshatriya duty, one should first welcome the guest and then, in accordance with proper conduct, give alms to the wandering ascetic.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: In the prosperity of learning and penance, the sacrificial offerings made into the sacred fires led by the brahmin serve to ward off great sins and misfortunes.

sloka: tapasa॒: tatmahi॒naajāya॒taekam
translation: Through tapas, we meditate on the one non-decaying entity.

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: Indeed, the divine and immortal being, the person, is both within and beyond all things, unborn, without breathing, free from desires, pure, surpassing all physical elements, and supreme.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the previous age, among the gods, there was a birth that always existed. At the beginning of the first age, another birth that always existed also occurred. From that, hopes and expectations then sprouted forth for all created beings.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: The truth is one, but the learned speak of it variously.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: In the beginning, only the unmanifest existed. From that, the manifest was born. The manifest then created itself. Therefore, it is called "created by itself." Indeed, that creation is pleasure itself.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: In the beginning, only the unmanifest existed. Then the seers asked, "What was here before, or who created this (unmanifest)?"

sloka: so'yaṃ puruṣaḥ prajāpatirakāmayata bhūyāntsyāṃ prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata sa śrāntastepāno brahmaiva prathamamasṛjata
translation: This creator Purusha, Prajapati, desired to multiply the creation. After practicing austerities, exhausted, he created first of all Brahma.

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation: Nothing here in front, at the very beginning, ever truly existed as death; this world is not covered by it. The mind, seeking 'I-ness', creates the delusion of death. Engaging in worship, one finds the waters of life; they nourish the worshipped and become dear to the worshiper.

sloka: nāsa̭dāsī॒nno sadā̭sītta॒dānī॒m nāsī॒drajo॒ no vyo̭mā pa॒ro yat| kimāva̭rīva॒: kuha॒ kasya॒ śarma॒nnaṃbha॒: kimā̭sī॒dgaha̭naṃ gabhī॒ram ||
translation: Uninvited, you never existed; you are always present here and now. You are not inferior or superior. What are you like, where do you come from, and whose protection do you seek? What is your purpose, and why do you occupy such a vast expanse?

sloka: na mṛ॒tyurā̭sīda॒mṛta॒ṃ na tarhi॒ na rātryā॒ ahna̭ āsītprake॒taḥ| ānī̭davā॒taṃ sva॒dhayā॒ tadeka॒ṃ tasmā̭ddhā॒nyanna pa॒raḥ kiñca॒nāsa̭||
translation: Death did not exist nor immortality, neither in the beginning nor at any later time, nor was there the division between night and day. That single breath of life, born of itself, was all that existed then. There was no other thing apart from it.

sloka: tama̭ āsī॒ttama̭sā gū॒l̤hamagrḙ'prake॒taṃ sa̭li॒laṃ sarva̭mā i॒daṃ| tu॒cchyenā॒bhvapi̭hita॒ṃ yadāsī॒ttapa̭sa॒stanma̭hi॒nā jā̭ya॒taika̭ṃ|| ||
translation: When primordial darkness, the sticky and all-encompassing ignorance, was fully manifest before the creation, then the one pure consciousness appeared.

sloka: kāma॒stadagre॒ sama̭varta॒tādhi॒ mana̭so॒ reta̭: pratha॒maṃ yadāsī̭t| sa॒to bandhu॒masa̭ti॒ nira̭vindan hṛ॒di pra॒tīṣyā̭ ka॒vayo̭ manī॒ṣā||
translation: At the forefront of desire, when it is first enveloped by mental resolve, and resides in the heart as the primary thought - such is the pure bond that is devoid of impurities.

sloka: ti॒ra॒ścīno॒ vita̭to ra॒śmirḙṣāma॒dhaḥ svi̭dā॒sī du॒pari̭ svidāsī t| re॒to॒dhā ā̭sanmahi॒māna̭ āsantsva॒dhā ā॒vastā॒tpraya̭tiḥ pa॒rastā̭t||
translation: Desiring to attain strength and nourishment, we should approach the green plants growing on the earth, which are free from attachment and are luminous. Let the growth and well-being of all be ours. May our endeavors be successful.

sloka: ko a॒ddhā vḙda॒ ka i॒ha pra vo̭ca॒tkuta॒ ājā̭tā॒ kuta̭ i॒yaṃ visṛ̭ṣṭiḥ| a॒rvāgde॒vā a॒sya vi॒sarja̭ne॒nāthā॒ ko vḙda॒ yata̭ āba॒bhūva̭ ||
translation: Who among the learned in this world today is first to speak auspicious words, and from where has such excellence arisen? Who has been the one to manifest and set in motion his glorious beginnings?

sloka: i॒yaṃ visṛ̭ṣṭi॒ryata̭ āba॒bhūva॒ yadi̭ vā da॒dhe yadi̭ vā॒ na| yo a॒syādhya̭kṣaḥ para॒me vyo̭ma॒ntso a॒ṅga vḙda॒ yadi̭ vā॒ na veda̭|| ||
translation: Superior prosperity indeed originated if, indeed, it came into being or not, who truly knows regarding the one established in the highest and all-pervading —the embodied consciousness , or if not .

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The treatise that reveals the extraordinary means to obtain what is desirable and avoid what is undesirable is called Veda.

sloka: mantra brahmanyor vedanāmadheyam
translation: The object of meditation in the mantra is Brahman (the ultimate reality) and the Vedas.

sloka: brahmamukhanirgatadharmmajñāpakaśāstram iti purāṇam
translation: The scripture known as "Brahma-mukha-nirgata-dharma-jñāpaka" is ancient.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Therefore, the Ṛc, Sāman, and Yajus are the means of consecration.

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: This, the exhaled manifestation of the great entity, is surely the Ṛkveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda, as well as the Āṅgirasa.

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The teachings of the Vedanta shastras are divine discourses that elucidate and establish dharma and brahman.

sloka: na vedaśāstrādanyattu kiṃcicchāstraṃ hi vidyate | niḥsṛtaṃ sarvaśāstraṃ tu vedaśāstrāt sanātanam ||
translation: Nothing apart from the Vedas is a true source of knowledge, for all other teachings originate from the Eternal Veda.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: And thus revealing through direct perception and inference.

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Let the gifts given to mothers, fathers, teachers, guests, and those who are in need, devoted servants, and the most excellent of the destitute become fruitful.

sloka: śrotriyāya daridrāya gṛhasthāyāgnihotriṇe| putradārābhibhūtāya tathā hyanupakāriṇe|| evaṃvidheṣu dātavyā na samṛddheṣu bhārata|
translation: To the learned poor man, a householder performing the agnihotra ritual, one who has overcome the desire for sons and spouse, as well as to one who does not deserve charity – these are the ones who should be given to, but not in times of prosperity, O Bharata.

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: Offered to the deceitful, fickle-minded boaster and miser, as well as to those who are experts in dishonest practices, a gift becomes unfruitful.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation: From the unmanifest, all manifest beings emerge in this cycle of day and night, and there they merge back into the unmanifest. Therefore, the nature of things is such that while individual forms may perish, the eternal essence remains unaffected. This eternal essence, beyond the transient appearance and disappearance of forms, is called the imperishable and is considered the ultimate goal.

sloka: taddha tadvanaṃ nāma tadvanamityupāsitavyaṃ sa ya etadevaṃ vedābhihaina~ sarvāṇi bhūtāni saṃvāñchanti || ||
translation: That which is called its distinctive name , that should be worshipped ; who knows only this through the Vedas , all beings associate with it.

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: Like how one speaks to a dear woman.

sloka: priyo hi jananinotyārthaṃ aham sa ca mam priyaḥ
translation: For I am dear to them and they are dear to me.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: Five are the household duties of a grihastha (householder): serving elders, protecting dependents, performing religious rites, giving gifts, and receiving hospitality. One who engages in transporting should observe restraint in these areas.

sloka: adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pitṛyajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo balirbhautī nṛyajño'tithipūjanam ||
translation: The ritual of teaching is the Brahma-yajna, while tarpanam is the pitri-yajna; offerings to gods is homa, to bhutas (elements) is bali, and hospitality to guests is nry-yajna.

sloka: tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: The one who makes offerings into the fire is a god-worshipping yajña, who offers oblations is a nature-worshipping yajña, who gives to the ancestors is an ancestor-worshipping yajña, who studies the Vedas is a brahma-worshipping yajña, and who gives to humanity is a human-worshipping yajña. These various forms of yajñas should be performed.

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: By being completely absorbed in the correct performance of the fifth major sacrifice.

sloka: pañca vā ete mahāyajñā: satati pratāyante satati saṃtiṣṭhante devayajña: pitṛyajño bhūtayajño manuṣyayajño brahmayajño iti iti
translation: Indeed, these five are the great sacrifices: always established and offered up are the divine sacrifice, the sacrifice to the forefathers, the sacrifice to beings, the sacrifice to humans, and the sacrifice to Brahman.

sloka: tatra devayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadagnau juhotyapi samidhaṃ taddevayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti puroḍāśādihavirmukhyaṃ tadalābhe samidhamapyagnau devānuddiśañjuhotīti yatso'yaṃ devayajñaḥ
translation: The definition of the Devayajna ritual is given: it is when a sacrificial fire offering is made in the agni (fire), like the addition of samidha (fuel). This very Devayajna thrives in the primary havishyas (oblations) such as purodasha, during its performance. And when there is a scarcity of fuel, even then, offerings are made to the gods in that same agni by indicating them. Such is this Devayajna.

sloka: bhūtayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadbhūtebhyo bali~ harati tadbhūtayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti
translation: The characteristic of the sacrifice to beings is described as follows: taking offerings from beings, that is the sacrifice to beings; it sustains (or exists) thus.

sloka: manuṣyayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadbrāhmaṇebhyo'nnaṃ dadāti tanmanuṣyayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti
translation: The definition of a human sacrifice (manuṣyayajña) is stated: it subsists by giving food that is not to be eaten by Brahmins.

sloka: brahmayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatsvādhyāyamadhīyītaikāmapyṛcaṃ yaju: sāmaṃ vā tadbrahmayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti svasyāsādhāraṇatvena pitṛpitāmahādiparamparayā prāptā vedaśākhā svādhyāyaḥ tatra vidyamānamṛgādīnāmanyatamamekamapi vākyamadhīyīteti yatso'yaṃ brahmayajñaḥ
translation: The definition of the Brahma-yajna is given: one should study every day a single verse from the ṛc, yajuḥ, or sāman branches of the Vedas, which have been passed down through generations as part of one's daily duties . This is considered to be the Brahma-yajna. Additionally, one should also strive to understand any other teachings found within this verse.

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: Sacrifice, referred to as yaga, is the relinquishment of material offerings specifically designated for the deity. It is called "homa" when such offerings are thrown into the fire.

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four priests, namely the darśa, pūrṇamāsa, ṛtvij, and adhvaryu, along with brahmā, hotā, and āgnīdhra.

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛk‌sāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The combination of fees for the officiating priests, the sacrificial grass, and the animal offerings is called a yajna (sacrifice).

sloka: ayam yajna vishvasya bhuvanasya nabheehi
translation: This sacrifice is the support of all creation.

sloka: gṛhasthasya kriyātyāgo vratatyāgo vaṭorapi tapasvino grāmasevā bhikṣorindriyalolatā āśramāpasadā hyete khalvāśramaviḍambanāḥ devamāyāvimūḍhāṃstānupekṣetānukampayā
translation: For the householder who has renounced actions and vows, even the ascetic who serves the village and the mendicant who is entangled in the objects of the senses – these are, in truth, deceivers of the ashrama, deluded by divine illusion. They should be overlooked with indifference, yet also regarded with compassion.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Having offered oblations of sweet milk to the Krttikas, the most fortunate one should appease the worthy Brahmins and only then can attain the highest realms.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: You, who nourishes the Ṛc chants, are praised by those who blossom in sacred hymns, sung in the assemblies. To you, Brahmā speaks in the born-of-learning (jāta-vidyā), setting the measure of the sacrifice.

sloka: avināśi tu tadviddhi yena sarvamidaṃ tatam | vināśamavyayasyāsya na kaścitkartumarhati || ||
translation: Indeed, understand that to be indestructible, by which all this is pervaded; none can cause the destruction of the imperishable.
