sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
translation: Who, then, is the Vrtra (an Asura defeated by Indra)? According to the Nairuktas, he is the cloud (Megha). In the traditional accounts (Itihasas), Tvastri is referred to as an Asura. From the mixture of water and light, the function of rain-making arises. In this context, the color of battle is determined by a comparison to that particular object.

sloka: iṣumātramiṣumātravvi~ṣvaṅṅavardhata sa imāllo~kānavṛṇodyadimāllo~kānavṛṇottadvṛtrasya vṛtratvantasmādindro'bibhedapi
translation: May Isumatri, single-handed, increase in strength; for only she can completely vanquish the enemy Vrtra, becoming its death and ending its role as a vritra (obstacle).

sloka: atṛpṇuvantaṃ viyatamabudhyamabudhyamānaṃ suṣupāṇamindra sapta prati pravata āśayānamahiṃ vajreṇa vi riṇā aparvan
translation: Perceiving the unconsciously expansive and the one who is sleeping Indra , strike the enemy with your thunderbolt , separating him in an unprecedented way .

sloka: samudrajyeṣṭhāḥ salilasya madhyātpunānā yantyaniviśamānāḥ indro yā vajrī vṛṣabho rarāda tā āpo devīrihamāmavantu
translation: May the foremost of the oceans, the purest waters that flow everywhere in the middle region of salilasya, along with Indra who hurls lightning (vajrī) and is like a bull (vṛṣabhaḥ), bestow their power upon me.

sloka: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye'bravīnmanuḥ | | | |
translation: Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, cleanliness, and sense control - these, Manu proclaimed, constitute the collective duty for the four social classes.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyam akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten characteristics of dharma are: patience, forgiveness, self-control, non-stealing, cleanliness, sense restraint, understanding, wisdom, truthfulness, and absence of anger.

sloka: paropakārāya phalanti vṛkṣāḥ paropakārāya vahanti nadyaḥ | paropakārāya duhanti gāvaḥ paropakārārthamidaṃ śarīram || satyaṃ vada | dharmañcara | svādhyāyānmā pramadaḥ | ācāryāya priyaṃ dhanamāhṛtya prajātantuṃ mā vyavacchetsīḥ | satyānna pramaditavyam | dharmānna pramaditavyam | kuśalānna pramaditavyam | bhūtyai na pramaditavyam | svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam || ||
translation: Trees bear fruits for the benefit of others, rivers flow for the benefit of others, and cows yield milk for the benefit of others. This body is meant for the service of others. Speak the truth, follow dharma, do not be negligent in your studies and teaching, give preference to the teacher's well-being, do not be neglectful in discharging your duties towards your family, always speak the truth, follow dharma, act skillfully, strive for prosperity, and do not be neglectful in studying and teaching.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam | mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava | yānyanavadyāni karmāṇi tāni sevitavyāni | no itarāṇi | yānyasmākaṃ sucaritāni | tāni tvayopāsyāni | no itarāṇi || || sukhārthinaḥ kuto vidyā nāsti vidyārthinaḥ sukham | sukhārthī vā tyajedvidyāṃ vidyārthī vā tyajet sukham ||
translation: One should not be neglectful towards the duties of the gods and ancestors. Regard your mother as a goddess, your father as a god, your teacher as a god, and your guest as a god. Perform only those actions that are auspicious; abandon the rest. Whatever good deeds we have, they should be worshipped by you, not abandoned. For a seeker of happiness, there is no knowledge; for a seeker of knowledge, there is no happiness. If one desires happiness, they should renounce knowledge; if one desires knowledge, they should renounce happiness.

sloka: imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave'bravīt
translation: I conveyed this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan; he spoke it to Manu, who declared it to Ikshvaku.

sloka: evaṃ paramparāprāptamimaṃ rājarṣayo viduḥ sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa
translation: Thus, the royal sages of yore knew this traditionally-received yoga, but it has been lost in this current vast period of time, O scorcher of foes.

sloka: yattadadreśyamagrāhyamagotramavarṇaṃmacakṣuḥśrotraṃ tadapāṇipādam nityaṃ vibhuṃ sarvagataṃ susūkṣmaṃ tadavyayaṃ yadbhūtayoniṃ paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ
translation: The wise perceive that which is not visible or graspable, without attributes, beyond the reach of sight and hearing, all-pervading, subtle, immutable, and the source of all things.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati amataṃ mataṃ avijñātaṃ vijñātaṃ iti
translation: That which is unseen in darkness, through which the unheard becomes heard, the unknown known - such is it.

sloka: prāṇabandhanaṃ hi mana
translation: The mind is indeed the bond of the life force.

sloka: sa ya eṣoഽṇimā aitadātmyamidam sarvaṃ tat satyam sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who truly knows this self as the inner controller of all things , know that to be the truth . You are that .

sloka: krodhāyāḥ kanyakā jajñe dvādaśaivātmasaṃbhavāḥ | tā bhāryā pulahasyāsannāmato me nibodhata || || mṛgī ca mṛgamandā ca haribhadrā tvirāvatī | bhūtā ca kapiśā daṃṣṭrā ṛṣā tiryā tathaiva ca || || śvetā ca saramā caiva surasā ceti viśrutā | mṛgyāstu harigāḥ putrā mṛgaścānye śaśāstathā || ||
translation: The unmarried daughter of Krodhavaha gave birth to twelve manifestations of herself. Listen carefully, she became the wives of Pulahasya with the names Mrigi, Mrgamanda, Haribhadra, Iravati, Bhuta, Kapisha, Damstra, Rsia, Tiryaka, Sвета, Sara, and Surasaa. These, along with Mrgya, Hargaa, Putra, Mrga, and other Shaasha, are well-known.

sloka: dullolakaṃ lalohaṃ ca saramā dvau vyajāyata || ||
translation: The churning rod and the pestle were born, trembling and bubbling with excitement.

sloka: viśve asyā vyuṣi māhināyāḥ saṃ yadgobhiraṅgiraso navanta utsa āsāṃ parame sadhastha ṛtasya pathā saramā vidadgāḥ
translation: The all-pervading one , who is inside this moving and non-moving creation, shines through his own brilliance. He is the supreme sustainer of the established order , who constantly causes to flow the nectar of that established order.

sloka: anūnodatra hastayato adrirārcanyena daśa māso navagvāḥ | ṛtaṃ yatī saramā gā avindadviśvāni satyāṅgirāścakāra ||
translation: Following the lord of mountains, a sage with reverence, every ten months, one should perform a ritual using new shoots; for in such a way, Sarma and Angira came to know the truth of all things.

sloka: sthūlaśarīraṃ kim ? pañcīkṛtapañcamahābhūtaiḥ kṛtaṃ satkarmajanyaṃ sukhaduḥkhādibhogāyatanaṃ śarīram asti jāyate vardhate vipariṇamate apakṣīyate vinaśyatīti ṣaḍvikāravadetatsthūlaśarīram |
translation: What is the gross body? It is made up of five primary elements, produced by past actions and serves as the site for experiencing pleasure, pain, and other sensations. It arises, grows, changes, declines, and ultimately perishes in a six-fold manner.

sloka: sūkṣmaśarīraṃ kim ? apañcīkṛtapañcamahābhūtaiḥ kṛtaṃ satkarmajanyaṃ sukhaduḥkhādibhogasādhanaṃ pañcajñānendriyāṇi pañcakarmendriyāṇi pañcaprāṇādayaḥ manaścaikaṃ buddhiścaikā evaṃ saptadaśākalābhiḥ saha yattiṣṭhati tatsūkṣmaśarīram |
translation: The subtle body, what is it? It is made up of the five subtle elements, born from past actions, and serves as the basis for experiencing pleasure, pain, and other sensations. It consists of the five knowledge-conducting senses, the five action-conducting senses, the five vital airs, the mind, and the single intelligence, all of which exist together in a collection of seventeen components.

sloka: kāraṇaśarīraṃ kim ? anirvācyānādyavidyārūpaṃ śarīradvayasya kāraṇamātraṃ satsvarūpā'jñānaṃ nirvikalpakarūpaṃ yadasti tatkāraṇaśarīram |
translation: What is the causal body ? It is the non-designatable, beginningless ignorance that serves as the mere cause of the two bodies , and that pure consciousness of unchanging nature that exists.

sloka: atha tatpūrvakaṃ trividhaṃ anumānaṃ pūrvavat śeṣavat sāmānyatodṛṣṭaṃ ca |||| {anumānalakṣaṇam}
translation: Then, inference is threefold, preceding like (in the case of) a cause, following like (in the case of) an effect, and based on general observation. {Definition of Inference}

sloka: tatpūrvakamityanena liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbandhadarśanaṃ liṅgadarśanaṃ cābhisaṃbadhyate | liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbadhdyordarśanena liṅgasmṛtirabhisaṃbadhyate | smṛtyā liṅgadarśanena cā'pratyakṣaḥ arthaḥ anumīyate |
translation: By observing the sign (of the deity) through this (specific method) is the relationship between the sign and the one associated with it realized; by directly observing the sign is its remembrance established; through remembering the sign, the unseen object is inferred.

sloka: prajñātena sāmānyātprajñāpanīyasya prajñāpanamupamānamiti | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya iti | yadā khalvayaṃ gavā samānadharmaṃ pratipadyate tadā pratyakṣatastamarthaṃ pratipadyata iti | samākhyāsambandhapratipattiḥ rūpamānārtha ityāha | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamāne prayukte gavā samānadharmamarthamindriyārthasannikarṣādupalabhamāno asya gavayaśabdaḥ saṃjñeti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyataiti | yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇi yathā māṣastathā māṣapaṇi ityupamāne prayukte upamānāt saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyamānastāmoṣadhīṃ bhaiṣajyāyāharati | evamanyo apyupamānasya loke viṣayo bubhutsitavya iti |
translation: Explaining the general as "this is comparable to that" is understanding; for example, "like a cow" refers to the qualities of a cow . When this very thing becomes identical with the common characteristics of cows , then the true meaning is directly grasped . This is called "the relationship between a word and its referent" . For instance, when it is said "this is like a cow" , the word "cow" indicates the common characteristics of cows . Similarly, when it is said "this is like Mudga" or "like Mudga-parni", then one should understand the connection to the referent . Thus, this medicine is taken for that purpose . Indeed, whatever is desired in the world should be understood in this way.

sloka: aāptaḥ khalu sākṣātkṛtadharmā yathādṛṣṭasyārthasya cikhyāpayiṣayā prayukta upadeṣṭā | sākṣātkaraṇamarthasya āptiḥ tayā pravarttata ityāptaḥ | ṛṣyāryyamlecchānāṃ samānaṃ lakṣaṇam |
translation: Undoubtedly, the true nature of dharma is made evident when properly pointed out to one who has seen it for themselves. This realization of truth and obtaining of right knowledge is what I call apta. There is a common characteristic between ṛṣis and barbarians in this regard.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and scriptural testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti |
translation: There are respectively the following branches of knowledge: in that realm, the Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda; also Shiksha (phonetics), Kalpa (rituals), Vyakarana (grammar), Nirukta (etymology), Chandas (prosody), and Jyotisha (astronomy).

sloka: tathā copapurāṇāni munibhiḥ kathitāni ca | mahāpurāṇānyetāni hyaṣṭādaśa mahāmune ||
translation: Similarly, the eighteen Mahapuranas have been recounted by sages, as well as some Upapuranas.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva dānaṃ pātre pratigrahaḥ| adhyāpanamadhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgṛjuḥ||
translation: Performing rituals for others, self-performed rituals, giving charity, receiving alms in a worthy vessel, teaching and learning are the six duties that constitute religious observance.

sloka: satyaṃ dānaṃ kṣamā śīlamānṛśaṃsyaṃ tapo ghṛṇā | dṛśyante yatranāgendrasa brāhmaṇa iti smṛtaḥ ||
translation: Recognized as a brahmin is one who exemplifies truth, charity, forgiveness, self-control, non-ridicule, and austerity, at the sight of whom (others) become endowed with compassion.

sloka: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānām akalpayat ||
translation: Prescribed for Brahmins are teaching (adhyapana), studying (adhyayana), performing ritual sacrifices (yajana), assisting at others' rituals (yajana), giving (dana), and accepting (pratigraha), respectively.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ śrutyuktaḥ smārta eva ca | tasmādasminsadā yukto nityaṃ syādātmavāndvijaḥ ||
translation: The supreme duty is to follow the established code of conduct, as stated in both scriptural testimony and traditional teachings. Therefore, a twice-born person should always be united with it as their constant duty.

sloka: nākasya pṛṣṭhe adhi tiṣṭhati śrito yaḥ pṛṇāti sa ha deveṣu gacchati | tasmā āpo ghṛtamarṣanti sindhavastasmā iyaṃ dakṣiṇā pinvate sadā ||
translation: The one who sustains on the peak of the sky, from whom rain is poured out, truly goes among the gods. Therefore, rivers always swell with water and ghee; hence this southern offering (of oblation) always thrives.

sloka: sa tu dānasya tattvārthī tepe varṣagaṇānbahūn|| || ā āī ēē ṣṇāū|| || tatastaṃ prāha khe vāṇī ślokamekaṃ nṛpa śrṛṇu|| dvihetu ṣaḍadhiṣṭhānaṃ ṣaḍaṃgaṃ ca dvipākayuk|| || catuḥprakāraṃ trividhaṃ trināśaṃ dānamucyate||
translation: That truth-seeker, indeed, endured heavy showers of alms-giving. Then, in the form of a sloka, transmitted from the sky, O king, listen to this: Alms-giving is said to have three aspects, four characteristics, six causes, and six bases; it is also categorized as having three destructive effects.

sloka: yujyante saṅklpyante sambadhyante parasparamarthāḥ samyaktayā prākaraṇike'bhimate'rthe virodhavyāghātādidoṣamapāsyānayā iti yuktiḥ yuj yojane tasmin yaktiriti rūpaṃ bhavati
translation: The art of joining consists of properly aligning things that are mutually related in the right place and time , avoiding conflicts and harm caused by inherent faults through careful elimination of such defects. This is the form that proper connecting takes.

sloka: yathā'mbujavanasyārkaḥ pradīpo veśmano yathā || prabodha prakāśārthāstathā tantrasya yuktayaḥ | ekasminnapi yasyeha śāstre labdāspadā matiḥ|| sa śāstramanyadapyāśu yuktijñatvāt prabudhyate |
translation: Just as the sun is the lamp for a lotus in bloom, and knowledge is the illumination of the scripture, so too is understanding the meaning of a single aspect of a treatise enough to become quickly proficient in that scripture.

sloka: dharmamūlaṃ vedamāhuḥ grantharāśimakṛtrimam| tadvidāṃ smṛtiśīle ca sādhvācāraṃ manaḥpriyam ||
translation: The root of dharma is declared to be the Vedas, abundant in collections of texts and untainted. For those who know it, proper conduct that is dear to the mind is established in the form of smriti.

sloka: dṛṣṭo dharmavyatikramaḥ sāhasaṃ ca mahatāṃ || ̥ṣṭō ḥ āṁ āṁ || iti| sāhasaṃ paraśurāmādeḥ mātuḥ śirachedādi|
translation: Witnessed for violating dharma, Parashurama, the mighty, began to sever his mother's head and so on.

sloka: anānmāteṣu dharmeṣu kathaṃ syāditi cedbhavet | yaṃ śiṣṭā brāhṇā bhrūyuḥ sa dharmassyādaśāṅketaḥ|| | |
translation: How could there be a doubt about this matter concerning dharma (duties/righteousness) among the wise brahmins? The one who is proclaimed as such by them, he indeed represents dharma.

sloka: anānmāte daśāvaraiḥ śiṣṭaiḥ ūhavadbhiḥ alubdhaiḥ praśastaṃ kāryam| yattaiḥ praśastamityuktaṃ tatkāryamityarthaḥ|
translation: The noble task indicated by "praśasta," spoken of by the honest and unenvious experts, should be understood as "kārya" (what ought to be done) through those very means that make it "praśasta."

sloka: catvāro vedadharmajñāḥ pariṣatraividyameva vā| sā brūte yaṃ sa dharmassyādeko vā'dhyātmavittamaḥ||
translation: The four knowers of the Vedic duties, should they be wandering about or thoroughly studying, declare that one supreme personal duty that is related to self-realization.

sloka: yenāsya pitaro yātāḥ yena yātāḥ pitāmahāḥ| tena yātātsatāṃ mārge tena gacchannariṣyati||
translation: By which [yena] his ancestors have departed, by which [tena] also have his great-grandfathers; he will also proceed [gacchann Ariṣyati] on that path [satām mārge] traversed by the virtuous [yena āsya pitaraḥ yātāḥ yena pitāmahāḥ yātāḥ].

sloka: pramāṇato'rthapratipattau pravṛttisāmarththadarthavat pramāṇam | tasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya samīhā pravṛttirityucyate | dvayorekatarasya cāpi asannikṛṣṭārthaparicchittiḥ pramā tatsādhakatamaṃ yattattrividhaṃ pramāṇaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The means of comprehending the purpose, i.e., pramana, is effective in establishing the intended meaning when it comes to establishing the certainty of an object in the context of two or more than two things, as well as for a single object. It is said that the intention or desire (samihah) of a person who is not using words (ajihahasya), is referred to as pravrtti, or inclination. This type of pramana, which establishes the intended meaning in various ways, is threefold and is known as sankhya sutra - the source of correct knowledge about an object's significance through the establishment of its close connection with other objects, either individually or collectively.

sloka: agniṃ parisamūhya brahmacārī tūṣṇīṃ samidhamādadhyāt tūṣṇīṃ vai prājāpatyaṃ prājāpatyo brahmacārī bhavatīti vijñāyate
translation: Having gathered firewood silently, the student of sacred knowledge silentely kindled the fire, and came to be known as one who follows the orders of Lord Brahma, thus realizing "Prājāpatyaḥ" (the descendant of Lord Brahma) becomes a brahmacārī.

sloka: sa idbhojo yo gṛhave dadātyannakāmāya carate kṛśāya | aramasmai bhavati yāmahūtā utāparīṣu kṛṇute sakhāyam || balaṃ balavato naśyedannahīnasya dehinaḥ| tasmādannaṃ viśeṣeṇa śraddhayāśraddhayāpi vā|| ādatte hi rasaṃ sarvamādityaḥ svagabhastibhiḥ| vāyustasmātsamādāya rasaṃ megheṣu dhārayet|| tattu meghagataṃ bhūmau śakro varṣati tādṛśam| tena digdhā bhaveddevī mahī prītā ca bhārata|| tasyāṃ sasyāni rohanti yairjīvantyakhilāḥ prajāḥ| māṃsamedo'sthimajjānāṃ sambhavastebhya eva hi||
translation: The householder who gives food to the desireless and the thin, becomes worthy of respect for that guest. And he gains friendship by sharing food with others even beyond his capacity. The strength of the weak does not diminish if he eats with faith and devotion. For, the sun extracts its juices from everything, then air absorbs those juices in the clouds, and Indra showers them down as rain upon the earth. Thus nourished, the earth brings forth crops that sustain all living beings – meat, fat, bones, and marrow come into existence only for their sake.

sloka: yanna prāpyaṃ tadaprāpyaṃ vidyayā pauruṣeṇa vā | satyo lokapravādo'yaṃ nādattamupatiṣṭhati ||
translation: Without acquiring which, not acquiring which, through knowledge or strength, this world's convention of truth does not stand firm.

sloka: na tasmātparamaṃ dānaṃ kiñcidastīti me manaḥ| annātprāṇabhṛtastāta pravardhante hi sarvaśaḥ|| tasmādannaṃ paraṃ loke sarvalokeṣu kathyate| annādbalaṃ ca tejaśca prāṇināṃ vardhate sadā||
translation: "In my opinion, there is no gift superior to food. Indeed, for all beings sustained by life energy, food promotes strength and vigor. Therefore, in every world, food is said to be the foremost."

sloka: asurāḥ paṇayo nāma rasāpāranivāsinaḥ | piveyaṃ tu payastāsāṃ gavāṃ yāstā niguhatha | asurāstāṃ tathetyuktvā tadājahuḥ payastataḥ sā svabhāvācca laulyācca pātvā tat paya āsuram |
translation: The named cooks, referred to as the asuras, reside near the liquor stores. One should drink the fee of their cows, which has been withheld, at that time. Having said this, they used to drink (the fees) back then due to their nature and greed. Therefore, that which is drunk from them becomes asuric.

sloka: śataṃ caikā hṛdasya nāḍyaḥ tāsāṃ mūrdhānamabhiniḥsṛtaikā tayordhvamāyannamṛtatvameti viṣvaṅṅanyā utkramaṇe bhavanti
translation: A hundred and one are the vessels of the heart , from their top arises the ūrdhvaṃ path leading to immortality . The others leave through different openings.

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: A brahmin is to be known by birth; a dvija (twice-born) by samskaras (rituals). Through learning, one becomes a vipra (priest). The three attributes of shrotriya (knowledgeable of Vedic hymns), lakshana (having distinctive marks), and prayaḥchitta (expiation) constitute discrimination.

sloka: dvividhā tu khalu tadvidyasaṃbhāṣā bhavati sandhāyasaṃbhāṣā vigṛhyasaṃbhāṣā ca |
translation: Indeed, the speech of the knowers of the Truth is of two kinds: one that is smooth and accepted, and another that is harsh and rejected.

sloka: tatra jñānavijñānavacanaprativacanaśaktisampannenākopenānupaskṛtavidyenānasūyakenānuneyenānunayakovidena kleśakṣameṇa priyasambhāṣaṇena ca saha sandhāyasambhāṣā vidhīyate |
translation: There, with (the help of) the wise one, endowed with knowledge, understanding, speech, counter-speech, power, and accomplishment; free from anger, respectfully approached by knowledge, free from envy, able to be approached, and an expert in instruction; with a calming and pleasant conversation, together with proper conduct, is established.

sloka: jñānagrahaṇābhyāsastadvidyaiśca saha saṃvādaḥ || ||| taṃ śiṣyagurusabrahmacāriviśiṣṭaśreyo'rthibhiranasūyubhirabhyupeyāt || || pratipakṣahīnamapi vā prayojanārthamarthitve || ||
translation: Engaging in the practice of acquiring knowledge, conversing with knowledgable ones, identifying the worthy student-teacher-companion, and pursuing it without envy, even if against opposing views, for the purpose of obtaining ultimate benefit.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||||
translation: The method of debate is characterized by reliable means of knowledge, logical reasoning, supporting evidence, consistency with established principles, comprising five limbs, and addressing both one's own and opposing viewpoints.

sloka: sa jalpo vitaṇḍā bhavati kiṃ viśeṣaṇaḥ pratipakṣasthāpanayā hīnaḥ |
translation: That [sa] dispute and verbal dueling [jalpaḥ vitaṇḍāḥ] becomes what [bhavati] special quality [viśeṣaṇaḥ] is lacking [hīnaḥ] in the establishment [sthāpanayā] of a counter-argument.

sloka: svapakṣarāgeṇa caike nyāyamativartante taca | tattvādhyavasāyasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ jalpavitaṇḍe bījaprarohasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ kaṇṭakaśākhāvaraṇavat || ||
translation: Some, adhering to their own doctrine, deviate from the correct principle; for the protection of the established understanding of truth and for nurturing the growth of the seed of knowledge, like a thorny branch, one engages in polemics.

sloka: anutpannatattvajñānānāmagrahīṇadoṣāṇāṃ tadarthe ghaṭamānānāmetaditi |
translation: Of those who have not yet fully realized the true nature of things and are free from inherent faults, for that purpose (tadarthe) they are engaged in collecting this (etat).

sloka: budhajanairvādaḥ parityajyatām ||
translation: Reject the debate led by the ignorant.

sloka: sampātirnāma nāmnā tu cirañjīvī vihaṅgamaḥ| bhrātā jaṭāyuṣaḥ śrīmānvikhyātabalapauruṣaḥ||||
translation: The bird named Sampati, known for his long life and exceptional strength, is the brother of Jatayus.

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yannu ma iyaṃ bhagoḥ sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syātkathaṃ tenāmṛtā syāmiti neti hovāca yājñavalkyo yathaivopakaraṇavatāṃ jīvitaṃ tathaiva te jīvitaṃ syāt amṛtatvasya tu nā''śā'sti vitteneti
translation: Maitreyi asked, "How can this whole earth filled with wealth make me immortal?" Yajnavalkya replied, "Just as the life of inanimate objects depends on their maintenance, so does your life depend on it. But immortality is not achievable through wealth."

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yenāhaṃ nāmṛtā syāṃ kimahaṃ tena kuryām | yadeva bhagavānveda tadeva me brūhīti
translation: Maitreyi asked: "What must I do to attain immortality? Kindly inform me of that very thing, as revealed by the Supreme Lord."

sloka: sa yathā saindhavakhilya udake prāsta udakevānuvilīyeta na hāsyodgrahaṇāyeva syāt yato yatastvādadīta lavaṇameva evaṃ vā ara idaṃ mahadbhūtamanantamapāraṃ vijñānaghana eva etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānuvinaśyati na pretya saṃjñāstotyare bravīmiti hovāca yājñavalkyaḥ
translation: Just as the salt dissolves in the sea water and is not distinguished separately, similarly, after emerging from these great elements (earth, water, fire, air, space), one merges back into them without leaving a distinct identity. Yajnavalkya said this.

sloka: svīryateḥ vā | suvateḥ vā | sūryaḥ sarteḥ vā |
translation: Either the powerful one (suggests a heroic or solar deity) or the giver (suvateḥ), the sun (suryaḥ) is distinct (riteḥ).

sloka: citraṃ devānāmudagādanīkaṃ cakṣurmitrasya varuṇasyāgneḥ | āprā dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣaṃ sūrya ātmā jagatastasthuṣaśca ||
translation: A marvelous spectacle is the gathering of the gods, the eye of Mitra, Varuna, and Agni, the sky between heaven and earth, the sun's self, and the sustainer of the universe.

sloka: yo'sau tapannudeti | sa sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇānādāyodeti | asau yo'stameti | sa sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇānādāyāstametiṃ |
translation: The one who stimulates warmth (tapam) and gives life breaths (pranan) to all beings, is he who raises and lowers them.

sloka: avati trīnimā~llokān yasmātsūryaḥ paribhraman || avidhātuḥ prakāśākhyo hyavanātsa raviḥ smṛtaḥ || ||
translation: The sun, known as the "source of light," illuminates the three worlds. How is this achieved by Surya?

sloka: tat sūryasya devatvaṃ tanmahitvaṃ madhyā kartorvitataṃ saṃ jabhāra yadedayukta haritaḥ sadhasthādādrātrī vāsastanute simasmai
translation: That is the divinity of the sun, and its greatness, which, being in the middle as the agent, holds (illuminates) everything here from day to night; thus, it is always established in its own form for this (universe).

sloka: ārogyaṃ bhāskarādiccheddhanamiccheddhutāśanāt | īśvarājjñānamicchecca mokṣamicchejjanārdanāt || ||
translation: Seeking health from the sun's rays, eliminating impurities through fire, desiring knowledge from the Lord, and compassion for living beings from Janardana – these are the pursuits.

sloka: sūryaḥ ātmā jaṅgamasya ca sthāvarasya ca | | |
translation: The soul of both the mobile and the immobile, that is the sun.

sloka: ṛgbhiḥ pūrvāhṇe divi deva īyate | yajurvede tiṣṭhati | madhye ahnaḥ | sāmavedenāstamaye mahīyate | vedairaśūnyastribhireti sūryaḥ |
translation: In the early morning, the divine sun illuminates the sky through its rays; it resides in the Yajurveda at midday; pervades the earth with the Sama Veda as twilight approaches; and when devoid of the three Vedas, it is known as the sun.

sloka: dhruveṇādhiṣṭitaścaiva sūryo'po gṛhya varṣati || tadeṣa dīpta kiraṇaḥ sa kālagnirdivākaraḥ || || parivarttakramādviprā bhābhirālokayan diśaḥ || sūryaḥ kiraṇajālena vāyuyuktena sarvaśaḥ || || jagato jalamādatte kṛtsnasya dvijasattamāḥ || ādityapītaṃ sakalaṃ somaḥ saṃkramate jalam || ||
translation: The sun, stationed in Dhruva, begins to rain; then its intense rays, like a blazing fire, illuminate all directions with its beams. The sun, moving in its orbits, pervades the air with its rays. The best of the twice-born takes in the entire solar light and water of the world. Soma moves through all the water taking on the color of pure gold.

sloka: hriyanharistairharibhisturaṃgamairharatyathāpaḥ kiraṇairharidbhiḥ || visargakāle visṛjaṃśca tāḥ punarbibhartti śaśvatsavitā carācaram || ||
translation: At the time of discharge, the rays release and then continuously support the mobile and immobile universe, carrying heat and energy, just as a lover passionately embraces their beloved.

sloka: suṣumno harikeśaśca viśvakarmā tathaiva ca | viśvaśravāḥ punaścānyaḥ saṃyadvasurataḥ paraḥ || arvāvasuriti khyātaḥ svarakaḥ sapta kīrtitāḥ | suṣumnaḥ sūryaraśmistu puṣṇāti śiśiradyutim ||
translation: The revered Susumna and Harikesha, as well as the universal creator, are known by the names Samyatvasurata and Arvavasu. They are celebrated as Svaraka and Saptakirtita. They nourish the cool splendor of the sun-rays.

sloka: saṃsthitenaikacakreṇa paṃcāreṇa trinābhinā || hiraṇmayena bhagavāṃstathaiva haridarvaṇā || ||
translation: Established in a single wheel, with three spokes and five spokes unattached, thus is the golden (hiraṇmayena) and shining (harit) form of the divine (bhagavān).

sloka: sa tasya brahmaṇā sṛṣṭo ratho hyarthavaśena tu || asaṃgaḥ kāṃcano divyo yuktaḥ pavanagairhayaiḥ || ||
translation: That chariot, created by Brahma for him, is detached and made of divine gold, yoked to horses that are swift as the wind.

sloka: āvṛttā vālakhilyaiste bhramaṃte rātryahāni tu || vacobhiragryairgrathitaiḥ stūyamāno maharṣibhiḥ || ||
translation: Perturbed by the Valakhilyas' daily curses, they (Valakhilyas) wander around; being praised with foremost words by the great sages.

sloka: vālakhilyā nayantyastaṃ parivāryodayād ravim |
translation: The  Vallakhilyas direct their gaze towards the sun as it rises, referring to the first rising of the sun.

sloka: ete tapanti varṣanti bhānti vānti sṛjanti ca | bhūtānāmaśubhaṃ karma vyapohantīha kīrttitāḥ || ete sahaiva sūryeṇa bhramanti divi bhānugāḥ | vimāne ca sthito nityaṃ kāmage vātaraṃhasi ||
translation: These [sunlight, rain, etc.] that cause heat, rain, shine, emit, and create, are known to remove unfavorable deeds of living beings. They constantly revolve together with the sun in the sky, reside in the wind full of desire on the divine plane.

sloka: sūryeṇa viṣuvaṃ vidyā tkālaṃ somena lakṣayet || samā rātrirahaścaiva yadā tadviṣuvaṃ bhavet || ||
translation: The knowledge of the solstice can be determined by the sun, and similarly, the six months [can be determined] by the moon. Likewise, day and night are considered to be a solstice when they become equal.

sloka: devaliṅ‌gapraticchannaḥ svarbhānurdevasaṃsadi | praviṣṭaḥ somamapibat candrārkābhyāṃ ca sūcitaḥ || ||
translation: Having disguised himself in the assembly of gods, resembling a divine fire, he entered and was indicated by the moon and sun as having consumed the soma offering.

sloka: sūtrārtho varṇyate yatra padai: sutrānusāribhiḥ| svapadāni ca varṇyante bhāṣyaṃ bhāṣyavido vidu: ||
translation: Where the meaning of aphorisms is explained by footnotes and their own words are also described in the commentary, knows that scholar of commentaries.

sloka: sumitriyā na ' āpa ' oṣadhayaḥ santu durmitriyās tasmai santu yo 'smān dveṣṭi yaṃ ca vayaṃ dviṣmaḥ ||
translation: May harmful plants not approach us, who are enemies of our foe; let beneficial ones come to our friend Sumitra.

sloka: ekaṃ sadviprā bahudhā vadantyagniṃ yamaṃ mātariśvānamāhuḥ ||
translation: The single, truth, scholars call by various names such as fire, Yama, and Mātariśvan.

sloka: saṃgaṭhana sūktam saṃvanana āṅgirasaḥ| agniḥ saṃjñānam| anuṣṭup triṣṭup| saṃsa॒midyṷvase vṛṣa॒nnagne॒ viśvā̭nya॒rya ā | i॒l̤aspa॒de sami̭dhyase॒ sa no॒ vasū॒nyā bha̭ra || saṃ ga̭cchadhva॒ṃ saṃ va̭dadhva॒ṃ saṃ vo॒ manā̭ṃsi jānatām | de॒vā bhā॒gaṃ yathā॒ pūrvḙ saṃjānā॒nā u॒pāsa̭te || sa॒mā॒no mantra॒: sami̭tiḥ samā॒nī sa̭mā॒naṃ mana̭: sa॒ha ci॒ttamḙṣām | sa॒mā॒naṃ mantra̭ma॒bhi ma̭ntraye vaḥ samā॒nena̭ vo ha॒viṣā̭ juhomi || sa॒mā॒nī va॒ ākṷ̄tiḥ samā॒nā hṛda̭yāni vaḥ | sa॒mā॒nama̭stu vo॒ mano॒ yathā̭ va॒: susa॒hāsa̭ti ||
translation:
Assembling hymn of Āṅgirasa, named "Saṃgaṭhana,"
Agni is the recognition,
In Anuṣṭup and Triṣṭup meters,
In the shared abode of Dyaus and Prthivī,
You are invoked, O Vṛṣaṇna, the powerful one among the Angirases,
Together with the Vasus, may you strengthen us.

Gather together, consecrate together, let your minds be one,
As the divine beings did of old at their invocation.

The Samāna mantra is "samitiḥ samānī" (let all come together),
With the Samāna mantra I invoke you, may it bring us together.

Samānī is the hearing, Samānā are the desires in your hearts,
May there be unity among you, as with a beautiful laugh.

sloka: jagrāha pāṭhyaṃ ṛgvedāt‌ sāmabhyo gītameva ca yajurvedādabhinayān‌ rasamātharvaṇādapi||
translation: He took up, for recitation, the  Ridge Veda, and the Saman (Sama Veda) indeed, as well as the Yajur Veda, skillfully drawing out the essence from Atharva Veda.

sloka: sāmavedādidaṃ gītaṃ saṃjagrāha pitāmahaḥ
translation: Grandfather embraced this sung (hymn) from the Saama Veda.

sloka: mātā bhūmiḥ putro'haṃ pṛthivyāḥ |
translation: I am the son, the earth is my mother.

sloka: ṛṣyaśṛṅgastu jāmātā putrāṃstava vidhāsyati sanatkumārakathitametāvadvyāhṛtaṃ mayā
translation: Rishyashringa, indeed, will establish your sons according to the teachings of Sanatkumara that I have recited so far.

sloka: yathā mātaramāśritya sarve jīvanti jantavaḥ | tathā gṛhāśramaṃ prāpya sarve jīvanti cāśramāḥ||
translation: Just as all living beings survive relying on their mothers, so do they all live in domestic ashrams.

sloka: upayuktaṃ ca yatteṣāṃ matimānnānuśocati || dharma ityeva saṅkalpya yastu tasya phalaṃ śṛṇu | sarvayajñapraṇītasya hayamedhena yatphalam | varṣe sa dvādaśe devi phalenaitena yujyate ||
translation: Considering dharma alone, the prudent one reflects on what is appropriate for them. Now hear about the fruit of this for one who has organized a sacrifice involving all the gods: in the eleventh year, O goddess, the fruit equates to a hundred cows from a single sacrificial horse.

sloka: śarīramekaṃ daṃpatyorvidhātrā pūrvanirmitam| tasmātsvadāranirato brahmacārī vidhīyate||
translation: The single physical form of the couple is created by a creator beforehand. Therefore, one who is attached to their spouse should be pursuing brahmacarya (celibacy).

sloka: ekenāṃśena dharmārthaḥ kartavyo hitamicchatā| ekenāṃśena kāmārthamekamaṃśaṃ vivardhayet||
translation: With a fraction of one's efforts, duty and wealth ought to be accomplished for the benefit of others; with another fraction, one should cause the growth of desires and pleasures.

sloka: saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: Upon your arrival as a guest, one should offer (you) a seat and water, and serve food according to one's ability, with respect and in accordance with custom.

sloka: paradāreṣvasaṃsargo nyāsastrīparirakṣaṇam| adattādānaviramo madhumāṃsasya varjanam || eṣa pañcavidho dharmo bahuśākhaḥ sukhodayaḥ| dehibhirdharmaparamaiśrvartavyo dharmasambhavaḥ||
translation: This fivefold duty, branching out with many benefits, is to be practiced regarding bodily matters; refraining from taking what has not been given and from eating meat, protecting women from improper advances, and abstaining from madhu (possibly an intoxicant) and māṃsasya (meat).

sloka: yaḥ śāstravidhimutsṛjya vartate kāmakārataḥ | na sa siddhimavāpnoti na sukhaṃ na parāṃ gatim || tasmācchāstraṃ pramāṇaṃ te kāryākāryavyavasthitau | jñātvā śāstravidhānoktaṃ karma kartumihārhasi ||
translation: One who abandons the rule of scripture and acts according to his own desires will not attain success, happiness, or the highest goal. Therefore, scripture is your standard in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having understood the dictates of scripture, you should be eager to perform that action.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: Purity (sattva) flourishes in happiness, passion (rajas) does so in activity, O Bharata; knowledge, when covered by ignorance and misunderstanding, is overcome by darkness.

sloka: yajante sāttvikā devānyakṣarakṣāṃsi rājasāḥ | pretānbhūtagaṇāṃścānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ ||
translation: The devoted ones of a satvic nature worship the gods, while those of a rajasic nature worship yakshas and rakshasas. Others, of a tamasic nature, worship ghosts and spirits.

sloka: aśāstravihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ | dambhāhaṃkārasaṃyuktāḥ kāmarāgabalānvitāḥ || karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṃ bhūtagrāmamacetasaḥ | māṃ caivāntaḥśarīrasthaṃ tānviddhyāsuraniścayān ||
translation: Those who practice austerities not prescribed by scripture, fierce in their behavior, driven by arrogance and self-interest, and infatuated with desires, torment themselves and the natural world within their bodies, as well as the divine essence within; recognize them as demonic in their certainty.

sloka: oṃtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇāstena vedāśca yajñāśca vihitāḥ purā ||
translation: The omniscient designation of Brahman is threefold: 'tatsat'. Long ago, sacrifices and the Vedas were ordained by brahmins who knew this.

sloka: aśraddhayā hutaṃ dattaṃ tapastaptaṃ kṛtaṃ ca yat | asadityucyate pārtha na ca tatpretya no iha ||
translation: Offered without faith, given, austerities performed, and actions done, all that is called Asadita by Partha, and neither here nor in the next world is it of any use.

sloka: uśanha vai vājaśravasaḥ sarvavedasaṃ dadau
translation: Undoubtedly, Ushan, also known as Vajashravasa, gave away all his possessions that were required to be offered in the Vedic rituals.

sloka: pītodakā jagdhatṛṇā dugdhadohā nirindriyāḥ
translation: Waters generated by churning of milk, originating from the earth, without senses.

sloka: sa hovāca pitaraṃ tata kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti
translation: He asked (his) father to whom I should serve/devote myself.

sloka: bahūnāmemi prathamo bahūnāmemi madhyamaḥ |
translation: Of the many (bahūnām), I am the first (prathamaḥ), I am also the intermediate (madhyamaḥ).

sloka: anupaśya yathā pūrve pratipaśya tathā pare | sasyamiva martyaḥ pacyate sasyamivājāyate punaḥ || ||
translation: Observe as before, and also see anew. Like a plant, the mortal is consumed and reborn again.

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ purā na hi suvijñeyamaṇureṣa dharmaḥ |
translation: Even the gods have previously doubted this (dharma) to be difficult to fully understand.

sloka: śāśvatī śabalā mahyaṃ kīrtirātmagato yathā asyāṃ havyaṃ ca kavyaṃ ca prāṇayātrā tathaiva ca
translation: My fame, eternal and strong, associated with my self, is like this sacrificial offering and poetry, as well as the journey of the life force.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The brahmin was born from his mouth, the kshatriya from his arms, the vaishya from his thighs, and the shudra from his feet.

sloka: sarvasyāsya tu sargasya guptyarthaṃ sa mahādyutiḥ | mukhabāhūrupajjānāṃ pṛthakkarmāṇyakalpayat | | | |
translation: For the protection of all that exists, the resplendent one assigned distinct actions to those with mouths, arms, and legs.

sloka: brāhmaṇānāṃ sito varṇaḥ kṣatriyāṇāṃ tu lohitaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ pītako varṇaḥ śūdrāṇāmasitastathā || ||
translation: The color of Brahmins is white, that of Kshatriyas is red, while Vaishyas have a yellowish hue, and the complexion of Shudras is blackish.

sloka: na viśeṣo'stivarṇānāṃ sarve brāhmamidaṃ jagat | brahmaṇā pūrvasṛṣṭaṃ hi karmabhirvarṇatāṃ gatam || ||
translation: No distinction exists among all colors in this world, for initially, the whole universe was created from Brahman and has become diversified through actions.

sloka: kāmabhogapriyāstīkṣṇāḥ krodhanāḥ priyasāhasāḥ | tyaktvasvadharmāraktāṅgāste dvijāḥ kṣatratāṃ gatāḥ || ||
translation: Those who are passionately fond of sensual pleasures, sharp-tongued, easily angered, and excessively proud; having abandoned their own dutiful conduct, those twice-born ones have become warriors.

sloka: gobhyo vṛttiṃ samāsthāya pītāḥ kṛṣyupajīvinaḥ | svadharmān nānutiṣṭhanti te dvijā vaiśyatāṃ gatāḥ || ||
translation: Engaging in their livelihoods to serve the cows, those who subsist on farming do not adhere to their own duties; instead, they fall into the behavior of vaishyas (merchants).

sloka: hiṃsānṛtapriyā lubdhāḥ sarvakarmopajīvinaḥ | kṛṣṇāḥ śaucaparibhraṣṭāste dvijāḥ śūdratāṃ gatāḥ || ||
translation: Those who are cruel, favor falsehood, greedy, and maintain themselves through all activities, who have fallen from purity, those twice-born ones have become outcastes.

sloka: ityetaiḥ karmabhirvyastā dvijā varṇāntaraṃ gatāḥ | dharmo yajñakriyā teṣāṃ na nityaṃ na pratiṣidhyate || ||
translation: Thus, these twice-born ones, having deviated from their own varna, are now classified as belonging to a different one through their actions. For them, dharma in the form of yajna rituals does not consistently become established.

sloka: śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt | svadharme nidhanaṃ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ || ||
translation: It is better to follow one's own duty, even if imperfectly, than to do another's perfectly. By following one's own duty, a person does not incur sin; by abandoning it, however, a great danger lies.

sloka: varaṃ svadharmo viguṇo na pārakyaḥ svanuṣṭhitaḥ | paradharmeṇa jīvanhi sadyaḥ patati jātitaḥ | | | |
translation: The proper course of action for oneself is superior to ill-performed duties prescribed for others; one instantly falls from their established status when they follow another's duty instead.

sloka: kadū mahīradhṛṣṭā asya taviṣīḥ kadu vṛtraghno astṛtam | indro viśvānbekanāṭā~ ahardṛśa uta kratvā paṇī~rabhi ||
translation: When indeed will the earth-disturber (asura) ever be vanquished, whose prowess is fierce like that of Indra, who has no equal, and who is accomplished in hard-to-achieve vows?

sloka: vadhīrhi dasyuṃ dhaninaṃ ghanena~ ekaścarannupaśākebhirindra | dhanoradhi viṣuṇakte vyāyannayajvānaḥ sanakāḥ pretimīyuḥ ||
translation: King Yudhishthira, with a single arrow and using only his sharp shooters, Indra-like, defeats the wealthy Dasyu; such is Sanaka's delight.

sloka: apāma somamamṛtā abhūmāganma jyotiravidāma devān | kiṃ nūnamasmānkṛṇavadarātiḥ kimu dhūrtiramṛta martyasya ||
translation: What now has become of us, who were immortal like the divine nectar, having approached the brilliant light-maker of the gods? Has mortality befallen us, or some deceitful treachery?

sloka: tasyāśitādyādāhārādbalaṃ varṇaśca vardhate yasyartusātmyaṃ viditaṃ ceṣṭāhāravyapāśrayam
translation: The strength and complexion of one who knows the nature of their sustenance and activities grow along with it.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: One who practices austerities obtains a long life, good memory, intelligence, excellent health, youthfulness, energy, strength of body and mind, eloquence, and brilliance, not through medicines or other means but through mastery over the senses.

sloka: ṛtvorantyādisaptāhāvṛtusandhiriti smṛtaḥ tatra pūrvo vidhistyājyaḥ sevanīyo'paraḥ kramāt asātmyajā hi rogāḥ syuḥ sahasā tyāgaśīlanāt
translation: The first of the six seasons, marked by the onset of rains, is known as ṛtu. The one who observes the rules of its beginning and end is remembered as pūrvaḥ vidhiḥ. Such a person should be followed; otherwise, diseases caused by imbalanced bodily humors may arise suddenly due to the neglect of these observances.

sloka: asātmyendriyārthasaṃyogaḥ prajñāparādhaḥ pariṇāmaśceti trayastrividhavikalpā hetavo vikārāṇāṃ samayogayuktāstu prakrutihetavo bhavanti |
translation: The three causes of the manifestation of physical transformations are: the improper connection with sense objects, intellectual transgressions, and the maturation of previous actions. These are specifically known as asātmya, indriya-ārtha saṃyoga, prajñā-aparādha, and pariṇāma. They occur when one's nature is influenced by distinct mental states.

sloka: kālārthakarmaṇāṃ yogo hīnamithyātimātrakaḥ| samyagyogośca vijñeyo rogārogyaikakāraṇam||
translation: The practice of aligning actions with their intended purposes is considered inferior when devoid of true understanding; the proper practice of yoga, however, should be known as the sole cause of both disease and its cure.

sloka: dhīdhṛtismṛtivibhraṣṭaḥ karma yatkurute aśubham| prajñāparādhaṃ taṃ vidyāt sarvadoṣaprakopaṇam||
translation: The one who is lacking in mindfulness and mental stability, commits evil actions; such a transgression of wisdom is the root cause of all afflictions.

sloka: daivamātmakṛtaṃ vidyāt karma yat paurvadaihikam smṛtaḥ puruṣakārastu kriyate yadihāparam
translation: Recognize that which is divinely predestined as having been done by the self, and recognize that which is performed by the individual as distinct from previous bodily actions.

sloka: atīndriyaṃ punarmanaḥ sattvasañjñakaṃ ‘cetaḥ’ ityāhureke tadarthātmasampadāyattaceṣṭaṃ ceṣṭāpratyayabhūtamindriyāṇām
translation: The mind, described as the apprehender of the subtle and called 'cetah', is the controller of the senses due to its inherent nature. This is the meaning given by the wise.

sloka: cintyaṃ vicāryamūhyaṃ ca dhyeyaṃ saṅkalpyameva ca yatkiñcinmanaso jñeyaṃ tat sarvaṃ hyarthasañjñakam indriyābhigrahaḥ karma manasaḥ svasya nigrahaḥ ūho vicāraśca
translation: That which is worthy of contemplation, to be analyzed, and also the object of meditation and resolution; whatever can be known by the mind – all of it is indicative of meaning, the focus of the senses, the action of the mind, and the control of one’s own actions.

sloka: sparśanendriyasaṃsparśaḥ sparśo mānasa eva ca dvividhaḥ sukhaduḥkhānāṃ vedanānāṃ pravartakaḥ
translation: The tactile sensation resulting from the contact of the sense organs with their respective objects, and the mental feeling of pleasure and pain - these are the twofold causes of the experience of sensations.

sloka: vedanānāmadhiṣṭhānaṃ mano dehaśca sendriyaḥ keśalomanakhāgrānnamaladravaguṇairvinā
translation: The support of sensations' experiences, the mind, and the body, along with the senses, are inseparable from the qualities of hair, skin, nails, their tips, food, impurities, and fluidity.

sloka: tatrendriyāṇāṃ samanaskānāmanupataptānāmanupatāpāya prakṛtibhāve prayatitavyamebhirhetubhiḥ
translation: The senses' uniform movement towards their respective objects, and the liberation from the suffering caused by their withdrawal, should be accomplished using those causes (the organs) according to their inherent nature.

sloka: yaccāpriyamapathyaṃ ca niyataṃ tanna lakṣayet
translation: What is considered displeasing and yet habitual, one should never overlook.

sloka: mṛjyate śodhyate iti |
translation: Should be cleaned, should be purified.

sloka: tatra śarīraṃ nāma cetanādhiṣṭhānabhūtaṃ pañcamahābhūtavikārasamudāyātmakaṃ samayogavāhi
translation: In that (tatra), the body (śarīram) is named (nāma), the basis of consciousness (ca eta na adhiṣṭhāna bhūta), made up of a combination (samudāya ātmakam) of the five (pañcama) great elements (ha ābhūta vikāra), and is the means (vāhi) of conjunction (sama yoga).

sloka: yadā hyasmiñ śarīre dhātavo vaiṣamyamāpadyante tadā kleśaṃ vināśaṃ vā prāpnoti
translation: When the imbalance arises in the bodily constituents (dhātavaḥ), then one gains either liberation from suffering (vināśam) or experiences suffering (kleśam).

sloka: kārtsnyena śarīravṛdhdikarāstvime bhāvā bhavanti
translation: With utmost effort, various states of being arise in one's physical existence.

sloka: sarve śarīradoṣā bhavanti grāmyāhārāt|
translation: All physical ailments arise from consuming domestic food.

sloka: tatra vaikārikādahaṅkārāttaijasasahāyāttallakṣaṇānyevaikādaśendriyāṇyutpadyante tadyathā śrotratvakcakṣurjihvāghrāṇavāgghastopasthapāyupādamanāṃsīti
translation: There, arising from the intellectual-ego and with the assistance of the fiery-energy, the following eleven organs of sense are produced: the ability to hear, touch, see, taste, smell, speak, grasp, procreate, evacuate, and the mind.

sloka: manaḥpuraḥsarāṇīndriyāṇyarthagrahaṇasamarthāni bhavanti
translation: The senses, located near the mind, become capable of grasping objects.

sloka: sendriyaṃ cetanaṃ dravyaṃ nirindriyamacetanam
translation: The conscious is with senses, while the insentient is without.

sloka: taddhyanutiṣṭhan yugapat sampādayatyarthadvayamārogyamindriyavijayaṃ ceti
translation: Upon focused meditation on That (Brahman), one immediately attains the dual victory of health and sensory mastery.

sloka: brahmacaryajñānadānamaitrīkāruṇyaharṣopekṣāpraśamaparaśca syāditi
translation: A brahmachari should be endowed with the giver of knowledge, compassion, joy, indifference, tranquility, and self-control.

sloka: āyurasmin vidyate anena vā āyurvindanti iti āyurvedaḥ |
translation: The science of prolonging life through this (knowledge) is called Ayurveda.

sloka: hitāhitaṃ sukhaṃ duḥkham āyus tasya hitāhitam | mānaṃ ca tacca yatroktam āyurvedaḥ sa ucyate ||
translation: That which describes (yatra) what is auspicious and inauspicious, pleasure and pain, the lifespan and its benefit or harm, as well as self-respect, is called Ayurveda.

sloka: dharmārthakāmamokṣāṇāmārogyaṃ mūlam uttamam || rogāstasyāpahartāraḥ śreyaso jīvitasya ca | prādurbhūto manuṣyāṇāmantarāyo mahānayam ||
translation: The ultimate root of dharma, artha, kama, and moksha is good health; the one who removes diseases is the great obstacle to humans and the means of their well-being.

sloka: satvamātmā śarīraṃ ca trayametattridaṇḍavat | lokstiṣṭhati saṃyogāttatra sarvaṃ pratiṣṭhitam | sa pumāṃścetanaṃ tacca taccādhikaraṇaṃ smrutam | vedasyāsya tadarthaṃ hi vedo ayaṃ prakāśitaḥ ||
translation: The self of pure consciousness , the body , and these three together are likened to a triple staff . The world rests on their union . All things are established in this. A being , consciousness , and its support are also remembered to be so. The meaning of this very Veda is revealed for understanding the purpose of the Veda.

sloka: tadidaṃ śāśvataṃ puṇyaṃ svargyaṃ yaśasyamāyuṣyaṃ vṛttikaraṃ ceti ||
translation: This is eternal, auspicious, heavenly, fame- and lifespan-enhancing, and a means of sustenance.

sloka: dhātusāmyakriyā coktā tantrasyāsya prayojanam ||
translation: The purpose of this system is to explain the harmonious functioning of its constituent elements . This has been stated in relation to the dhatus .

sloka: iha khalvāyurvedaprayojanaṃ vyādhyupasṛṣṭānāṃ vyādhiparimokṣaḥ svasthasya rakṣaṇaṃ ca ||
translation: In this context, the purpose of longevity is the release from disease for those afflicted with illness and the protection of health for the healthy.

sloka: sirāsnāyurajaḥstanyatvaco gativivarjitāḥ| dhātubhyaścopajāyante tasmātta upadhātavaḥ ||
translation: From sweat, hair, sinew, plasma, and skin, originating from elements, such byproducts are produced; therefore they are called upadhatu.

sloka: trividham khalu rogaviṣeśavijñānam bhavati tad yathā āptopadeśaḥ pratyakṣaṃ anumānaṃ ceti|–
translation: The knowledge of specific diseases certainly becomes threefold, namely through reliable instruction, perception, and inference.

sloka: prāgabhihitaṃ taddu:khasaṃyogāḥ vyādhayaḥ iti| tacca duḥkhaṃ trividhaṃ ādhyātmikam ādhidaivikam ādhibhautikamiti|
translation: Diseases, as mentioned before, are of three types: arising from the combination of the bodily humors, causing suffering that is respectively physical, divine, and demonic.

sloka: jāyate buḍhheravyaktādbuddhyā ahm iti manyante| paraṃ khādīnyahaṅkārādutpadyante yathākramam||
translation: From the undeveloped [state], understanding arises in the wise; they think 'I am' - such arise in order, following from individual consciousness.

sloka: avyaktaṃ mahānahaṅkāraḥ pancatanmātrāṇi ścetyaṣṭau prakṛtayaḥ śeṣāḥ ṣoḍaśa vikārāḥ|
translation: The unmanifest and the great self-consciousness , along with the five elements , are considered eight fundamentals . After these come the sixteen transformations .

sloka: sarvadā sarvabhāvānāṃ sāmānyaṃ vṛddhikāraṇam| hrāsaheturviśeṣaśca pravṛttirubhayasya tu||
translation: The increase or decrease is always the general cause of all beings' existence and their specific actions are also driven by it.

sloka: jāṭhareṇāgnināyogāt yadudeti rasāntaram| rasānāṃ pariṇāmānte sa vipākaḥ iti smṛtaḥ||–
translation: The agitation of the digestive fire in the stomach leads to the movement of a different taste from the original taste . This is known as the maturation of the tastes at the end of their transformation .

sloka: śarīrāvayavāstu paramāṇubhedenāparisaṅkhyeyā bhavanti atibahutvādatisaukṣmyādatīndriyatvācca teṣāṃ saṃyogavibhāge paramāṇūnāṃ kāraṇaṃ vāyuḥ karmasvabhāvaśca
translation: The parts of the body, (consisting of) atoms that are countless, extremely small, and beyond senses, are virtually innumerable due to their division. The cause of their joining and separation is the wind (vāyu), and (their) inherent nature is the performance of actions.

sloka: trividham khalu rogaviṣeśavijñānam bhavati tad yathā āptopadeśaḥ pratyakṣaṃ anumānaṃ ceti|–
translation: The knowledge of specific disease types is threefold: it comprises instruction from reliable sources, perception, and inference.

sloka: pratyakṣaṃ hyalpam
translation: Clearly (pratyakṣam), it is indeed (hi) insufficient (alpam).

sloka: athaupamyam aupamyaṃnāmayadanyenānyasyasādṛśyamadhikṛtyaprakāśanaṃ
translation: Now, something unparalleled, unable to be compared with anything else, and more excellent is being revealed/made manifest.

sloka: pūrvajanmakṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyādhirupeṇa bādhyate ||
translation: Born in a previous life's actions, sin takes the form of disease and afflicts.

sloka: yāvantāḥ loke mūrtimantaḥ bhāvaviśeṣāḥ tāvantāḥ puruṣe yāvantāḥ puruṣe tāvantāḥ loke ||
translation: To the extent that specific forms exist in the world, to that same extent do corresponding distinct states exist in a person; to that same extent do those distinct states exist in a person, and to that same extent does the world consist of those specific forms.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: One who practices (auspicious) behavior acquires a long life, good memory, intelligence, excellent health, youthfulness, strength in limbs, supreme mastery of speech, and radiance, not through the use of rejuvenating potions but as a result of meritorious actions.

sloka: cikitsā ruk pratikriyā|
translation: Treatment (or) cure for decay (or) deterioration.

sloka: yābhiḥ kriyābhirjāyante śarīre dhātavaḥ samāḥ sā cikitsā vikārāṇāṃ karma tadbhiṣajāṃ smṛtam kathaṃ śarīre dhātūnāṃ vaiṣamyaṃ na bhavediti samānāṃ cānubandhaḥ syādityarthaṃ kriyate kriyā
translation: By what actions are the identical constituent elements of the body produced, and how is the treatment of disorders considered to be their function? The consistent connection is made that there should not be any difference in the elements of the body, and this is accomplished through actions.

sloka: caturṇāṃ bhiṣagādīnāṃ śastānāṃ dhātuvaikṛte pravṛttirdhātusāmyārthā cikitsetyabhidhīyate
translation: The uniform purpose of the four types of healers (physicians, etc.) is called "cikitsa" and arises from a single root (i.e., the desire to cure).

sloka: apyevaṃ tu bhavet puṣpaṃ phalenānanubandhi yat | phalaṃ cāpi bhavet kiñcidyasya puṣpaṃ na pūrvajam || na tvariṣṭasya jātasya nāśo'sti maraṇādṛte | maraṇaṃ cāpi tannāsti yannāriṣṭapuraḥsaram||
translation: Even if it becomes like this, a flower is connected with its fruit; and indeed, some fruit exists for that which is the flower. For one who has just arisen, there is no destruction before death; and for that, there is no death, which is the foremost destroyer of the unripe.

sloka: mithyādṛṣṭamariṣṭābhamanariṣṭamajānatā ariṣṭaṃ vā'pyasambuddhametat prajñāparādhajam
translation: Misperceiving what is inferior as superior, or being unaware of what is truly auspicious, one considers something auspicious even when it's not; this is the result of a misunderstanding born from ignorance.

sloka: dūṣayanti iti doṣāḥ
translation: Those that tarnish (are) called faults.

sloka: vāyuḥ pittaṃ kaphaścoktaḥ śārīro doṣasaṅgrahaḥ
translation: The bodily constituents known as wind, bile, and phlegm have been described.

sloka: mānasaḥ punaruddiṣṭo rajaśca tama eva ca
translation: The mind is directed again towards the king, that is, towards passion and ignorance.

sloka: maitrī kāruṇyamārteṣu śakye prītirupekṣaṇam prakṛtistheṣu bhūteṣu vaidyavṛttiścaturvidheti
translation: Friendliness towards all, compassion for those in distress, ability to help those who are capable, indifference towards the unpleasant aspects of nature and a fourfold practice of therapeutic treatment for all living beings.

sloka: hetau liṅge praśamane rogāṇāmapunarbhave jñānaṃ caturvidhaṃ yasya sa rājārho bhiṣaktamaḥ
translation: The king who possesses fourfold knowledge that quells ailments through these two instruments (i.e., medicine and surgery) is the foremost healer.

sloka: dharmasyārthasya kāmasya nṛlokasyobhayasya ca dātā sampadyate vaidyo dānāddehasukhāyuṣām
translation: The physician becomes the giver of dharma's (righteousness) meaning, wealth's purpose, desire's fulfillment, and to people, the source of both physical comfort and longevity.

sloka: ruk vedanāyāyām|
translation: Relieving this pain, [is what] should be done.

sloka: nidāna pūrvarūpāṇi rupāṇyupaśayastathā saṃprāptiśceti vijñānaṃ rogāṇāṃ pañcadhā smṛtam|
translation: The knowledge about the preliminary symptoms, forms, progression, and manifestation is considered fivefold in understanding diseases.

sloka: tatra vikāraṃ hetudoṣadūṣyaprakṛtideśakālabalaviśeṣairliṅgataśca parīkṣeta na hyantareṇa hetvādīnāṃ balaviśeṣaṃ vyādhibalaviśeṣopalabdhiḥ
translation: There, one should examine the cause of change through factors such as inherent nature, location, time, and strength. Indeed, there is no recognition of a difference in the preponderance of causes and the preponderance of disease.

sloka: asātmyendriyārthasaṃyogaḥ prajñāparādhaḥ pariṇāmaśceti trayastrividhavikalpā hetavo vikārāṇāṃ samayogayuktāstu prakrutihetavo bhavanti |
translation: The three causes of the manifestation of physical transformations are: the inappropriate connection with the objects of the senses, intellectual transgressions, and changes brought about by the union of specific tendencies.

sloka: kālārthakarmaṇāṃ yogo hīnamithyātimātrakaḥ| samyagyogośca vijñeyo rogārogyaikakāraṇam||
translation: The true meaning of yoga for achieving the purpose of time (life) is not just mere mechanical performance; it should be understood as that which leads to both physical health and spiritual liberation.

sloka: te caturvidhāḥ āgantavaḥ śārīrāḥ mānasāḥ svābhāvikāśceti
translation: They are fourfold in nature, arising naturally from the physical and mental realms, respectively.

sloka: dhāraṇāt dhātavaḥ
translation: Due to retention (of essential nature), the elements (constituting the body).

sloka: dhātavaḥ punaḥ śārīrāḥ samānaguṇaiḥ samānaguṇabhūyiṣṭhairvā'pyāhāravikārairabhyasyamānairvṛddhiṃ prāpnuvanti hrāsaṃ tu viparītaguṇairviparītaguṇabhūyiṣṭhairvā'pyāhārairabhyasyamānaiḥ||
translation: The bodily tissues again and constantly regain growth through the intake of substances that have similar qualities , and they diminish through those that are opposite .

sloka: strīpuṃsayoravyāpannaśukraśoṇitagarbhāśayayoḥ śreyasīṃ prajāmicchatostadarthābhinirvṛttikaraṃ karmopadekṣyāmaḥ
translation: We shall instruct the action conducive to the welfare of the offspring that arises from the union of man and woman, which is yet unfertilized, containing both semen and menstrual blood.

sloka: tasyāmanupaghātāya paripūrṇatvāya sukhaprasavāya ca
translation: for its preservation, complete development, happiness, and easy manifestation.

sloka: dhruvaṃ caturṇāṃ sānnidhyādgarbhaḥ syādvidhipūrvakam ṛtukṣetrāmbubījānāṃ sāmagryādaṅkuro yathā
translation: Undoubtedly, a germination, as per the rules, will occur in the vicinity of four when it comes to the grain of the fields at the right time and place, just like the shoot from the seed.

sloka: dve vidye veditavye iti h sma yadbrahmavido vadanti parā caivāparā ca tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti atha parā yayā tadakṣaramadhigmyate
translation: The seers of Brahman have said that there are two kinds of knowledge to be known: the first one is the higher knowledge, and the other is the lower knowledge. The four Vedas, namely Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda, along with Shiksha (phonetics), Kalpa (rituals), Vyakarana (grammar), Nirukta (etymology), Chandas (metrics), and Jyotisha (astronomy), comprise the lower knowledge. The higher knowledge is that which leads to the understanding of the imperishable Brahman.
